reviewText: I actually saw this movie 3 times at the theater and enjoyed it just as much the 3rd time as the 1st. You smile the whole way thru. You just know that the cast had a terrific time making the movie. Looking around the theater I could see the majority of the people's heads bobbing with the music and as I sat there at the end and people were leaving they were actually singing along with the music at the credits. This is just a flat out FUN movie that left you feeling GREAT.

I sometimes wonder what movie the critics see because it rarely if ever matched the movie I see. I paid to see this movie five times and took my daughter four of those times, we LOVE it. I makes you feel good, the music gives you energy, to me the movie made me feel young and hopeful. The loctaion it was shot in was breathtaking, the chemisty on screen was wonderful! When it first came out it was not a trailer that grabbed me and I really had no interest in seeing it, but a friend of mine invited me and my daughter to go with her one night, and I am so glad we did. I shudder to think I almost missed one of the best big screen experiences I've ever had.

Saw the play in London, New York and D.C. and loved every minute!
Saw the movie when it came out this year and thought it was every bit as exiting as the play/musical. I simply can't wait to own the DVD when it is available!

From what I know of the history of this play/movie the two ladies that worked so hard to get ABBA and others to put this together in GB are now two of the wealthiest women in England - and from what I have seen it drives the critics nuts, ("lousy, bad camera work, Brosnen can not carry a tune etc., etc.,) the bottom line folks, this movie fits like that old comfortable shirt your wife (the critic) wants you to throw away because it looks "awful".  Well, the heck with em, I like my shirt, and I like meatloaf and mashed potatos, and I like Mama Mia, maybe it is mind candy, maybe it does not reach the high brow standard, but it "feels good" so the pundants can take their "expert" advise and put it where "the sun don't shine", this movie makes me smile and who knew Meryl Streep could sing like that - the "Winner Takes it All" maybe very poorly filmed according to the so called experts because the one I saw said "get me off the Merry-go-Round" but it sure sent chills down my back - let the experts rave - I know what I like, and this film made me laugh - in times like these I will take that any old time over what the high brows think I should see!

PS - as for Mr. Brosnan's singing and why he did the film - straight from the horses mouth -

Q. What drew you to this movie? A. My agent called and said, "Meryl Streep, Mamma Mia!," and I said, "I'm in!" I didn't even know who I was playing. I kept thinking, I want to work with this wonderful actress.

Q. How did you fare with all the singing you had to do for the role?
A. I've never done anything as orchestrated or musically complex in my life. At first, I just made noises. Then I went to London and trained in the studio with Benny [Andersson] and Bjrn [Ulvaeus] from ABBA. My family let me know that they were very worried for Dad when they first heard Dad sing. But sing I did.

I am glad to know "the dancing queen" is coming to dvd because I am 17 this year. My favorite song in the movie though is "Does Your Mother Know." I am getting really dizzy and I am not broken hearted anymore. I recommend anyone to see this and own it. I knew it was going to be on this special 2 disc DVD. I hope you get wild and let feel it. I think everyone is the Dancing Queen!! What special features I know will be deleated scenes, behind the scenes, and many other fabulous moments at the making of this film. Meryl Streep has brought the role of a women to be strong, funny, and always having that feeling of being young again. Remember to SOS this DVD. Chao!!!

The soundtrack of this film is actually what led me to watch it for the first time, and the movie packs so many different family stories into one plot. ABBA is a fantastic group, and this was my first Meryl Streep movie experience.
Sophie is getting married, and she was raised by a single mom. She wants her father to walk her down the aisle, so she invites all three of her possible dads to the wedding in the hopes that she will know which one she is related to. Sophie's mom, Donna, has no biological family, as they disowned her when she became pregnant out of wedlock. Her friends Tanya and Rosie have become family to her as a support system. Sophie's dads, Bill, Harry, and Sam eventually come to decide that they do not need to know which of them is her biological father because they have all formed relationships with her as father figures. Sophie calls off the wedding because she realizes that having the wedding just gave her something to prove, not more love for her fiance, Sky. Sam and Donna take advantage of this calling off to get married, because they have already paid for the entire thing. Then, Rose and Bill end up together because they have both been lone wolves and are finally ready to make a pack of their own. Finally, Harry comes out a gay man, and says that Donna is the only woman he ever loved.

Despite the great songs of ABBA, this is an example of non-musical actors trying their best to be musical.  While Streep can decently sing surrounding her with two other actresses (who are excellent actors) who equally aren't musical actors don't really help (Sorry, Christine and Julie).  I kept thinking - why not get Bette Midler as a co-star.  As great as Streep is as an actor, her movements as she decently sings her ABBA songs betray her lack of real musicality - so there is one thing she can't do as an actress after all.  After watching this great dramatic actress try to be truly graceful and musical, I now have a greater appreciation for musical stars of the past for how little acclaim (under appreciation) they received for talents that are truly difficult to express on film: Doris Day, Jane Powell, Debbie Reynolds, Judy Garland.  And then you have the actors - Pierce Bronson almost single handedly torpedoes the film with his so-call singing.  Truly dreadful.  The only worse musical film performance can be found by Lucille Ball in Mame.  I wouldn't have minded his singing being dubbed by some singer because his acting wasn't that bad.  I have the same concerns about La-La Land and their selected "musical" actors but at least in that film, the choreography and cinematography were brilliant.

Why was this movie made?

---Sorry, folks, but this was---beyond a doubt---the absolute WORST FILM I have seen since, "Plan 9 From Outer Space." I did a double-take when I saw a "74% approval" rating for this hideously awful, poorly directed, waste of good cellophane...WHAT on earth could my fellow reviewers be THINKING?!?

---First, a few truths: 1) I LOVE the music of ABBA (yes, it's kitschy---but, it's GREAT kitsch). 2) I LOVED the Broadway production of "Mamma Mia," (which I saw shortly after it premiered), so my --REVULSION--toward this film does not lie in its source material. 3) If ever there were a movie more hopelessly miscast....I can't think of one.

---Criticisms: The most obvious criticism is the one that confronts  the viewer the moment Streep's face first appears on the screen: like the majority of the cast, she is simply MUCH too old for the part ---and worse--she looks it..... Instead of a still-youthful, 38-year-old, mother of the bride (as the script calls for), who, throughout the musical, is supposed to rock to the tunes of her school days (almost indistinguishable from her younger self), we are treated to a post-menopausal granny, displaying many of the physical limitations of her years--while gallantly attempting physical challenges that are simply beyond her age....

---Despite the generously-cut wardrobe, hair extensions, lighting tricks and the magic of the best make-up pros in Hollywood, it is simply impossible to "suspend disbelief" --to the tune of 20 years. Compounding this, the actresses chosen to portray Streep's "girlhood friends" and former band mates look, if possible, even older than Streep (this was so obvious, that one gets the malicious conviction that they were chosen precisely BECAUSE they might make Streep appear younger, in comparison).

---Streep's "former beaus," in this production suffer from the same issue---although all three men appear to be (and are, in fact) ten years' junior to the women....In fact, this type of "age miscasting" is such a basic "No-No" in filmmaking, I can't shake the strong conviction that, like certain Golden Hollywood divas of yesteryear, Streep was humored by those who should have known better, but who stood in awe of her institutional icon status in the industry....Perhaps a self-deluded, last desperate grasp at youth drove Streep in her insistence to play a role that every professional around her must have known she was grossly ill-suited for...I don't know...All I DO know is that watching these silly women--who were long past the "mommy" stage, long past the "granny" stage (hell, the "band mates" looked as if they should have had ADULT grandchildren), attempting to "rock it," was more than I could bear (after the first "group number," I will admit to having "fast-forwarded" through every subsequent number those ridiculous-looking women performed)...

---After the disaster in casting, every other negative in the film appears mild in comparison---beginning with the amateurish and gaudy direction....REALLY? Garish lighting, combined with film shots and editing techniques largely confined (thank God) to the '70s was deemed a "winning technique?" (And, NO---the director was NOT attempting to "mimic" 70s-era kitsch); she TRULY felt she was engaged in ground-breaking film making, according to professional critics who spoke to her during production (perhaps that is why this was the first--and last--major production she has been engaged in)...

----MINOR issues (in comparison to the two former) are things such as: an absolute lack of musical ability (singing or dancing) in Pierce Brosnan....Ham acting in the extras which would make a pig ashamed....And, resting over the entire, rotten edifice, the noticeable CONVICTION from the actors involved that they were engaged in a "great" project, personally chosen by a "great" actress (well...two out of three ain't bad: Streep IS a great actress---usually possessed as well with a sense of which projects suit her abilities best (rather than choosing "Mama Mia," Streep would have been far better served by a good psychoanalyst---and a prescription for estrogen replacement therapy)...

----Final analysis: Run---don't walk---AWAY from this pathetic waste of: 6,000 heartbeats and 1,200 respirations that will NEVER be recovered...

Girl writes 3 men she knows her mother dated the year she was born to invite them to her wedding. Her thoughts are that one of them has to be her fathers as she never knew her father. And she wants her father to walk her down the aisle. They show up thinking that the girl's mother invited them, and they all are fond of her mother still (which is odd given one of them is now gay). In the end she never finds out which one is her father as they all accept her as their daughter and she accepts them as all her father (gag). She also decides not to bother getting married as she and her bf just want to go experience the world (double gag). All of this ending stuff (and much more nonsense) take place literally at the wedding as the couple stands before the minister reciting their vows.

So in other words it is a real family values picture. NOT. Just more liberal confusion being projected upon vulnerable youth (I assume that is the audience for this movie) so that they can continue being miserable and gripping for the rest of their lives. They try hard to project the "let's do whatever we want and do nothing and we will be happy" idea which is of course not reality. They throw the guy coming out of the closet and finding his young Greek bf in the mix. People just dancing around without a care in their minds . . . world . . . . Again not reality. The movie is a musical of course. And while Streep and Baranski can sing they were miscast in this movie. Baranski is too operatic for this role and Streep is too 70s elevator musical for this role. I have no idea who the short woman is. . . the British woman. She was just all over miscast here. Just stupid. Not goofy funny stupid. Just stupid. Speaking of British . . . it is overwhelming British accents you hear. And Brosnan cannot sing. His solos are just painful. Sad too. Also I hate when the sun is out and the movie makers do whatever they do to make it look night time . . . but you can see the sun shining off the water and the actors' hair/faces. Just makes it look creepy to me.

PLEASE NOTE: "Digital Copy Included" that is included 'expired' in 2012 and is not valid.  Advertising as such is misleading, especially when you specifically try to purchase for the purported inclusion. Additionally, the digital copy came as a CD.  Not certain how it would have worked if it wasn't expired (if I would have been able to apply it to my UV or Vudu library of digital copies), but I could not even get that far.
Now, don't get me wrong, I enjoy this movie and bought it for that reason.  It isn't an amazing movie, but I enjoy the movie and the songs (I'm sure most agree that Pierce Brosnan singing is NOT the best, but otherwise, the songs are enjoyable).  The one star is for this as a product and not as a movie.  As a movie I'd give it 3-4 stars.

My daughter and I have watched this movie together repeatedly.  We first saw it when she was sixteen and we've watched it together I don't know how many times since then.  Funny, spirited, sing-along kind of movie.  Happy, joyous, makes you think about what matters in life.  A total hit.  And I love that the actors sing their own songs. Fans of ABBA will cringe; young people who never heard of ABBA will never want to after these bad Karaoke remakes. To top it all, Meryl Streep [along with her three back-from-the-grave boyfriends], too old to be the grandma of the lead actress, does a poor job of playing her mother, a worse job with her "singing," and shows why so many people agree that she's overrated.

I rewatched it again the other night (it's been years since I watched it the first time)...& was just disgusted with how badly they messed it up.

Poor quality product. The  volume had to be raised and lowed as the disc played, there were a few places where the picture quality blurred.  The website had a misleading description, the site said factory wrapped / direct from the Studios.  After viewing the movie I suspected it must be a knock off product.  When I was inspecting all the printing on it I found it had stamped on the bottom back, over the clear wrap a difficult to notice disclaimer.  " DISC MADE  N NEXICO" I did not make a typing error, the I was missing, half the M was missing, the top of the D, the E was barely visible, also the O was barely visible.  I considered the price as low because it was not a recent movie, nor a blockbuster, I did not think it was because of quality.
I will go to a bookstore next week and see if I can purchase a "decent" copy.  I consider my self burned by Amazon and I have gotten the message, buy at a store where you can inspect the product.

I'm not a fan of musicals at all.  The only musicals I can tolerate and actually like you can count on both of my hands.  Mamma Mia is in that list.  It's fun, bright, happy, uplifting in scenery location and the music.  The music sounds good and it's got a good beat with great melodies and harmony.  They took a popular group in music history like Abba and they're performing those songs into a story with this gorgeous backdrop and great acting.  Then you add Meryl Streep to that mix and wow!  She's incredible in everything she does and this is no different.  You can't keep your eyes off her and how she fills up a screen with her vibrant energy.  She's got an entertaining supporting cast that rises to the occasion with her from Christine Baranski, Pierce Brosnan, Julie Walters, Stellan Skarsgrd, Colin Firth, to Amanda Seyfreid.  The journey of watching this movie makes your toes tap.

Sophie, the 20-year-old daughter of Meryl Streep's, was raised by her single mother. Sophie is getting married and she wants her father there to give her away. From reading Meryl's diary, Sophie discovers three potential suitors that were involved with Meryl the summer she was conceived: Harry (Colin Firth), Bill (Stellan Skarsgard), and Sam (Pierce Brosnan). Sophie invites all three, without Meryl's knowledge. Sophie was thinking she would instantly recognize her own resemblance in her biological father, but there were no obvious signs. All three men are convinced they are her father and each insist on walking her down the aisle. Twenty-two of ABBA's hits joyously celebrated.

I love Abba, but I hated this play and this movie.  So much that I started an online support group called "People Who Were Hurt By Mamma Mia." At its peak, the group had 82 members.  My friend talked me into seeing the movie even after I hated the play.  He agreed that, if he thought it was really bad, he would pay for my ticket and for a nice dinner.  When we walked out of the theater, he handed me the money for the ticket and said "Now where do you want to eat?" To this day, when he asks me to do something that I strongly think will be terrible, I just say "remember Mamma Mia?" and the discussion ends.  So I guess sitting through the movie got me a nice dinner and out of a lot of other crappy shows.  Still, one star is generous for this debacle that does its best to destroy a lot of great songs.

Nobody ever said being a mother was easy. So the devoted, hardworking mom, it stands to reason, would respect herself enough to protect her daughter from living the same degenerating life she found herself in.  Her life was fraught with complexity but could it be possibly from a life of jumping in bed with man to man?  Yes, just a story but not truly something we want our daughters mimicking  Horribly disappointing!  We had to fast forward to stomach the story line.  The acting was fair, the music fun, but the story was so far from true that I would sooner cry "Mercy!" than watch that or recommend it to anyone.  The ending is heart-wrenching.  I could never be happy with a man thrilled to commit to nothing but sex.  Wow!  Great job, Meryl Streep and Colin Firth...

I have seen "Mamma Mia" on stage three times and loved it so when the movie version came out on DVD I couldn't wait to purchase it, if only to hear Meryl Streep sing.
I very much enjoyed this cinematic version of the play, though not quite as much as when I saw it on stage. I'm not sure why that is, though it probably has something to do with the fact that the sweeping vistas in the movie were a little distracting. On stage, the audience focuses on the actors, the singing, and the dialogue. On the screen, the eye is drawn not to the actors as much as to the beautiful scenery that surrounds them.
That said, Streep does a wonderful job as the mom who has never quite grown up and the rest of the cast does the movie proud. The scenery is, as I said, spectacular and the cinematography does it justice. The direction is smooth, the dance numbers are well choreographed, and the costuming is very well done.
A solid 4 stars, maybe even 4.5.

This movie was probably the most boring 30 minutes that I ever spent.  I had to turn it off at the 30 minute mark.  A movie completely devoid of any substantive plot or memorable acting.  All the singing parts were boringly predictable and not very well executed.  If this is an example of America's attempt to produce a quality fun musical, God help us. We have reverted back to high school mundane music mentality.  The insertion of very "loud" intermissions of a meager attempts of Rock music between spoken parts completely ruined any hope of a redemption for the plot line!

Unfortunately Pierce Brosnan's singing pales in comparison,  but one quickly forgives that due to his appealing character and the high quality of the film from beginning to end. Highly recommend it  (and I rarely give anything five stars).

Who do you invite to your wedding? For one young girl that question includes 3 fathers.
Torrid affairs with three men (at three separate times, within a few weeks of each other), leaves Sophia inviting all of them to meet her father (WHICH ONE!) for the first time so he can give her away at her wedding.
Unbeknownst to her mother, of course.
The whole ABBA soundtrack makes you groove and dance along, and so what if some of the actors can't sing on pitch or key, I felt that made this movie way more realistic, and kept me from feeling bad when my own voice cracked or fell short.
The story is great, the acting is wonderful, and I've made this movie one of my go-tos for anytime I'm feeling blue and need to be reminded that I am the "Dancing Queen!"

Mama Mia is a quirky and elevating movie that partially centers around a strong bond that a woman named Sophie (Amanda Seyfried) has with her mother Donna (Meryl Streep). Donna is also lending emotional support to Sophie for her upcoming marriage and simultaneously coming to terms with Sophie growing up. On the positive/plus side both women are not alone as they are coping with the changes. In addition to her fiance Sky (Dominic Cooper), Sophie has her best friend Ali (Ashley Lilly) for support while her mom has support in the from Tanya (Christian Baranski) and Rosie (Julie Walters). Pierce Brosnan, Colin Firth, and Stellan Skarsgard also play roles in Mama Mia.

I am a huge Meryl Streep fan but was not thrilled with this film in any way.  Ms. Streep is always great in whatever role she plays but I thought her miscast in this type of film.  She is capable of playing comedic and musical roles, however, I found this far too light for her talents!  It's the film I don't particularly care for and even though many loved the long running play and the film...I'm just not one of them!  A bride-to-be, Sopie, played by Amanda Seyfried, is looking for her birth father to walk her down the aisle and in the chaos of preparations and invitations, the three possibles, Pierce Brosnan, Stellan Skarsgrd and Colin Firth show up for the wedding. Her mother, Donna, played by Meryl Streep, who once fronted the singing group, Donna and the Dynamos, is beside herself when they all appear in time for the week-end, Greek island wedding. Many private reminiscences, in flashback, occur for each of the main characters and it's all interspersed with tunes sung by ABBA!  I think the all around stand-out performance, belongs to Christine Baranski, as Tanya, who was one of Donna's Dynamos and still a good friend.  Julie Walters, as Rosie, brings up the rear as one of the old trio and is also pretty good in her role.

However, the bluray disk had a small, deep scratch on it that someone hid with a single smudged finger print on the disk... a sticky one that had dried on it... I cleaned it off with a dvd cleaner and microfiber cloth... and, only then found the deep scratch! It plays okay enough, my bluray player can handle it, but I paid for a brand new Bluray DVD, Not used or damaged... nor one that someone had intentionally tried to disguise a scratch from the buyer upon receipt... mine should have been placed into a used pile and replaced with another before being sent out. Poor choice on their part. I am disappointed when someone acts dishonestly with a customer, especially when I am that customer. I always strive to keep all my DVD's in perfect, scratch-free condition... I don't appreciate receiving them.

The film is art of the finest order.  First, needless to say, the music of ABBA transports the soul to a world of infinite joy and understanding.  The Buddhists call it Nirvana, but I call it Faltskog.  The dulcet tones of Dancing Queen will bring you to bliss.  AND NOT JUST THE HITS.  ALL THE SONGS ARE GREAT!!!!

Second, it touches on the breadth and depth of the human experience, such as "what is love and why do we pursue it?" and "is there a God and does she love us?".  Youth can learn from this.  Today's movies are all about sex and guns.  But what about love I ask you.  What about what binds us to our fellow man.  These are the topics that this film broaches.

Finally, the weight of those voices allowed me to soar to the depths of the ocean.  Pierce brought it.  He might not be the best voice, but if you imagine a trained singer singing it, not bad.  Also, Skarsgaard is a true talent...and in case you were thinking I forgot, Meryl is a Siren pulling us toward that ocean where they sail.

Would have been a 10 star movie, but it could have used more of Amanda's Seyfrieds.  FOR ADULTS ONLY: Check out Lovelace, you won't regret it!!!

It's amazing how a rather silly plot can make for such a fantastically fun film. Could it be the music of ABBA and all-star cast that makes MAMMA MIA! THE MOVIE a pure delight to the senses?
The story is fairly simple with one complication. Young Sophie has grown up on an idyllic Greek island with her single mother Donna. Sophie is about to get married and wants to invites the father that she has never met. There is one catch. Her father could be one of three men who breezed into Donna's life one summer. Somehow it all works thanks to the music of ABBA which is woven into the plot.
Donna's life churns with turmoil as she is faced with three men from her past who all realize they are Donna's father. Well, only one can be the father.
MAMMA MIA! THE MOVIE is the film to watch when you need a "lift" or a small and a laugh. It is pure joy and fun. Meryl Streep, Colin Firth, Pierce Brosnan. Christine Baranski,  Amanda Seyfried, and so on. Who could ask for a better cast and they all seem to be having the time of their lives in a film set in a gorgeous location. Come on. Admit it. The music of ABBA makes you smile so don't miss this movie!

Mamma Mia! does a so-so job at managing to craft a cohesive story using the lyrics of ABBA songs that weren't written at the same time. The songs performed during the bachelor and bachelorette parties are the best parts of the movie, and the bachelors' synchronized dance on the pier wearing flippers is visually entrancing. But it's Meryl Streep's singing that is surprisingly weak (I realize most of the actors are not professional singers but she more than others never seems like she's fully committed to it). This despite the fact she's playing a hippy character that's different than many of her other roles.

Okay, so we all want to visit the island, and sing the songs, and fall in love!  The music is ABBA; what more can I say!  There are Mamma Mia parties (usually to raise money for charities) across the country, and even in Central America.
Yea, I ordered it, "so what" I happen to like their music, and I'd order it again if the DVD did work, which it did, by the way!

There have been very few "Feel Good" movies in the last ten years or so. This one would arguably rank at the top if there were any others to which it could be compared. The visuals of the beauty of the Greek island setting are breath taking. The music of ABBA speaks for itself. And what can be said about Meryl Streep except that she is a national treasure. Consider the variety of characters that she has played in the last five years or so, each one to virtual perfection and what more can be said. Now we know that she can even sing and dance acceptably. Streep, with her two contemporary gal friends and former performer associates; Christine Baranski and Julie Walters are delights. Pierce Brosnan, Colin Firth and Stellan Skarsgard are the substantial male foils. For the younger set, Amanda Seyfried and Dominic Cooper are the eye candy, but, are not in the least, shallow characters. And the Chapel on the hilltop peninsula with its long stair way to climb is real, and can be found and seen on the island of Skopelos, Greece.

Meryl Streep has always been a favorite and she didn't disappoint in Mama Mia. This made for a great girls weekend and we all loved it.

The setting is in Greece, blue waters and warm sand.  The story is of wedding and the brides desire to have her father give he away.  The music is ABBA at it's best.  The actors and actresses are all top of the list.  So much enjoyment you will be dancing and singing along.

Meryl and Peirce make you believe that love can come around again even after 40.  Dominic and Amanda make you believe in young love.  Julie and Stellan make you believe that opposites can attract.  Christine makes you believe that you can find love with a younger man.  And, Colin makes you believe that love should be freely accepted regardless of who it is you are attracted to.

I give this musical two stars - one extra because I love the music, but not who sings them.  Amanda Seyfried does a very nice job but Pierce Brosnan, et al ruined it for me.  The story is clearly cheesy and from what I understand, was more or less made to fit already picked music, not the other way around.  Meryl Streep running around with the stringiest hair I've ever seen was not a fun image to say the least.  I can see the empowerment that this movie brings - especially to older women but sadly very few are familiar with the original songs and who sings them. The movie of course is great.  The Blu-ray is stunning.  The picture and audio are fantastic.  This is a great version.

But Colin Firth and Pierce Brosnan probably should stick to their day jobs of acting.

I'm not going to review the movie, because I think you either love it or hate it. Or somewhere in between.

I'm just going to critique some technical details.

1. The BluRay implementation was wonderful. The sound is perfect, and the video is in lustrous 1080p. The BluRay extras are fun, especially the director's commentary, which was better than a lot I've heard.
2. There's an implementation of some "pop-up" info-bites which you can enable, which gives you some more information. Not my thing, and very distracting. Turned it off.
3. Just a warning about the digital copy. It's SD instead of HD, which isn't what you get these days from most BluRay releases. So this must be an original BluRay version from a few years ago. Disappointing. Also, to download the digital copy you need a DVD player on your computer. I haven't had a DVD player on my computer in 2-3 years, so that made it basically useless.

If you want the BluRay disc because you love the movie, like I do, then this is an above-average implementation. Just realize the downloadable digital content is rather useless with those who have laptops without DVD players, and it's in old-fashioned SD quality.
this is a fantastic movie. I watched the live play and the movie did the play justice. The scenery was fantastic and Meryl Streep wonderful.

On subsequent viewings, although the plot is fine and nicely unfurls, I still cringe at some of the dialogue that (now) 3-time Oscar winner Meryl Streep, Emmy winner Christine Baranski (TV's "Cybill"), and Oscar nominee Julie Walters ("Billy Elliot") are forced to recite in "Mamma Mia" (more specifically, in about the first 30 minutes), especially after seeing Streep in the, of course, superior "Kramer vs. Kramer," a Best Picture winner, which is why I took one star away (I also can't help but wonder what this movie would've been like with, for example, John Travolta and Olivia Newton-John as the leads; dare to dream!).  Fortunately, however, there's enough of ABBA's irresistible and enduring music to pick up most of the pieces and to lift the entire cast to feel-good heights, making the cast themselves look like they are having a great time in basically a lavish ABBA karaoke-style party of a movie.  And it also helps that there's no weak link in the ABBA musical catalog, with my personal highlights being the lesser known gem "Our Last Summer" and, of course, Streep's undeniably solid and emotionally driven "The Winner Takes It All," right from the side of a mountain!  The rest of the very likable and energetic cast includes Pierce Brosnan, who was unnecessarily chastised by critics for his actually very respectable singing (let's see a critic belt out "S.O.S." as good as Brosnan did!), as well as Colin Firth, Stellan Skarsgard, the angelic Amanda Seyfried, and Dominic Cooper.  Another strength is its cinematic message that the older women and men in the leads can carry a movie just fine, thank you (as opposed to seemingly youth-targeted Hollywood).  No one can match the magic of the original ABBA music and singing, but this is probably the closest you can get without a genuine ABBA reunion.  Although it undoubtedly will be labeled a chick flick by most, if you like a feel-good movie with a happy ending, one that makes you want to watch it again and again, this one's made especially for you!  [Nerd fact #1: Executive producers for this film, those who invested their own money in helping it get made, include actor Tom Hanks and his wife/actress Rita Wilson; nerd fact #2:  the two original male members of ABBA make cameo appearances in the film, Benny Andersson during "Dancing Queen" and Bjorn Ulvaeus in the final scene that ends the credits; nerd fact #3:  Streep also sang in the dramas "Silkwood" (1983) and "Postcards from the Edge" (1990); Brosnan also sang in "Evelyn" (2002).]

It's the kind of stupid film which actually IS bad for people. It effectively validates and perpetuates a wholesale disregard of local culture or thoughtful, reasonable social behaviour.  It is about nothing more or less than a gang of self-obssessed rich children playing on someone else's beach, indulging every whim and caprice without the slightest regard for others or their local environment.

Oh yeah, a great one for the kids this !

A lovely, spirited romantic movie set in the beauty of Greece- its incredulous mountains and cliffs overlooking the sparkling blue sea looked down upon by bluer than blue skies. Whitewashed buildings made blindingly bright by the sun. The audience arrives at the scene along with the cast of attendees of Donna's daughter's wedding and the music draws us in to be full participants.

Donna had traveled to Greece as a seventeen year old young woman to enjoy a summer of the sights and carefree life there but never returned home - the consequences of casting fate to the wind and loving freely that impetuous summer.

Her light-hearted, free and easy ways of her youth had abruptly ended with that summer. As the movie begins, we learn that she has lived out her life over the past twenty years in financial hardship, having been disowned by her mother when her pregnancy was found out. The three young men with whom she had had romantic encounters that summer had moved on with their lives and never knew of her strife. Having the good fortune of inheriting a goat farm property on a precarious hillside, she has spent all her money and invested her back breaking labor in trying to restore the place into an Inn from which to draw an income. The reality was it was crumbling faster than she could repair it and no amount of whitewash could cover its decline.

What was planned as a simple village wedding ceremony with plenty of food and drink exploded over night into something quite unexpected as the guests begin to arrive and partake in the festivities. Donna is horrified when the three men - one of which was the father of her daughter - arrive on the scene. They had received invitations from her daughter whose deep-seated need to find out who her father overtakes all caution following finding her mother's diary about that summer and decides to invite the three possible "fathers" to her wedding - never really expecting any to come.

This convergence is rounded out by the arrival of Donna's two oldest and dearest friends from her back-in-the-day youth. The friendships of the young bride-to-be and her circle of close friends have their eyes opened to what her mother and friends had experienced in their youth as they provide the entertainment for the "girls only" party the night before the wedding by performing their array of disco songs. The young bride-to-be and her friends and the locals are shocked, but totally taken with the freeing tone those songs projected and the whole place goes crazy with everyone joining in along with the three men watching from the edge of the crowd as their old love, Donna, leads the 'playback" of songs and fun they had each personally shared with her as a young girl some twenty years before in this same breath-taking place.

The ending is a happy one. There is a message we come away with upon leaving the theater. For me it is, "Take time dear girls to form you own set of dreams. Find out who you are, recognize your talents, so that you can choose a career or path that will be the "work" of your life and also the source of what fulfills you outside of a relationship  - before the worldly responsibilities of becoming an adult are laid upon you.

Donna had swallowed the shame she felt in becoming an unwed mother. Rebuilding her crumbling property into an Inn became her life. An impossible dream given her financial resources yet she would not give up. Deep inside her, it represented a dream talked about with Sam back in that summer of long ago. A dream she would not let go of despite his no longer being there to share in it. For all its crumbling conditions, it was home for her and her daughter.

To ensure that unlike her, her daughter would find a safe and happy haven in life. The Rules would be followed! Her wings would be lovingly clipped to protect her from flying away to the temptations of inexperienced youth. A lovely wedding to remember, a devoted husband on which to depend BEFORE a baby came on the scene.... all would come to pass by following the "Rules".

While the memories of her daughter and her circle of friends are being formed, Donna's old memories - and those of the three men, come flooding back. They are both whimsical and lighthearted, filled with youthful innocence as they came to know one-another's budding interests and then gave way to their over-powering sexual attractions.  Yet the jarring and sobering realities that followed for Donna in how her life had played out after that summer of unfettered fun is unleashed in emotion as she sings, "The Winner Takes It All".

This is definately a "Chick Flick". Men will probably not come away with any of its deeper meaning. So see the movie with your girlfriends instead. Buy the CD and watch it alone to have a good laugh and cry when the load dumped upon your shoulders seems too much. Bring tissues because we women will cry when they see the parallels found in our own lives, others will cry for those in our sisterhood who gave up their young dreams and devoted the balance of their lives to making the most of their own dealt hand of reality. It reminds us of how restorative it is when we connect with our old friends and reminisce about the life journey we shared. But the movie's most important reminder is that there is nothing on earth to equal the deep and abiding connection between a man and a woman in love whose main expression of that love is to allow each to realize their dreams and be the support in those endeavors... It is such love that happens in both Donna's life and her daughter's that makes for the movies happy ending.

Review for 70's disco band ABBA and the piecemeal grouping of their songs into a show - mouthwash to get the sugary taste out of my mouth and reading a book to make up for the lost I.Q. points - not good. And you can't blame the era, because I would argue Tommy by The Who was near the same time period but didn't feel like the equivalent of babysitting a bunch of 11 year old girls. And sure musicals about promiscuity are some of the best and most respected musicals out there, thank you Camelot and Into the Woods, but I guess this did a good job of summarizing the carefree attitude of the '70s decade, which I'm not sad that I missed.
As for the movie I think it was a very good effort on the part of the cast for acting and singing. Meryl Streep had so much energy, at least some of it made it look as though she were genuinely having fun. She and Amanda Seyfried did an excellent job singing for non-singers. Most of the principal males had a little trouble with their songs, but they were pretty well perfectly cast for their parts anyway, no reason to complain. I get this was about dancing and singing, but there were times when there were close ups of singing and there was too much action. Twitching even? It's hard to be expressive with your face when you should be expressive with your voice, and some of the extraneous movement was disconcerting. A director should have told them to stop wiggling so much during those certain scenes. Even having the actors in question watch a musical or stage performance of a professional singer to learn how to hold their bodies and their faces and appendages while performing might have alleviated some of that.
The chorus was spot on most of the time for comic relief. There was a lot of pleasant and fun humor in the dances. However much of the story involving the older set of ladies was very blue collar humor, and it really made them all the more pathetic. Set and costume design was strikingly good, even if you haven't been to Greece you can get the feeling you've visited from the vibrant seaside decor and colors used here.
Don't think it's spoiling too much to say the daughter makes the "right" choice at the end to not go through with getting married, just like her mother did years before her. Good to know we haven't matured past the values of the '70s, or at least they want to relive their glory days.
I thought the film was marvelous. It was well acted and the cast had surprisingly good voices.  Any one who likes a good, light-hearted musical will love it1

I'm going back through all of my Amazon purchases beginning in 2001 and writing reviews for the notable products I've purchased over the years. By notable, I mean products that I am very happy with as well the ones that I now regret purchasing.

In the case of this movie, I bought it in 2010 and it easily fits into the Outstanding category - I've had it for 3 years and it I still plug it and watch it on a regular basis. What's not to love, it cinematographicly captures the true beauty of Greece, big name stars and the best music from ABBA.  I would definitely buy it again and highly recommend it to anyone considering purchasing it.

There were times, while watching this silly film, that I thought it might win me over through sheer exuberance.  But ultimately, it was not to be, for it suffers from two jointly-fatal flaws:  the whole is less than the sum of its parts; and the parts are less compelling than watching old ABBA videos.

I'll give one example of how the film works against itself.  "The Winner Takes it All" is a heartbroken lament by a betrayed woman as she parrots the cynical self-justifications of her betrayer.  It works (at least for me) because the heartbreak overwhelms the song and exposes the betrayer's self-serving cruelty.  Meryl Streep cannot sing quite as well as Agnetha, but she can act, and she acts her heart out while singing this to Pierce Brosnan.  But it is all for nothing, because the CONTEXT is all wrong.  He never betrayed her - it's all a silly misunderstanding.  And since he never said those things, the cynicism all comes from HER!  Whatever power the song ever had, it simply cannot survive this one-two punch of fake tragedy plus unsympathetic victim.

This happens repeatedly.  Not only does the story fail to add anything to the songs, but it actually works against the ideas or emotions the original songs seemed to convey.  Lyrics make poor sense in light of the plot (a woman singing "baby I'm still free" to a man she just met; a woman singing "building me a fence, building me a home" about a summer fling where she slept with 3 different men).

I won't pick on the quality of the singing, as some viewers do.  In fact, I think one of the most effective moments of the film is when the two sisters sing "Chiquitita" to Meryl Streep (badly, but with feeling!).  On the other hand, Amanda Seyfried sings quite well - but when she sings "I Have a Dream" I cannot remember why I ever liked the song.  Frida convinced me she really believed in angels, but somehow Amanda cannot.

Nor am I sure Amanda's renditions are the real problem.  There is something subtly wrong about the context - an aura of sad, sordid despair, thinly veiled by forced joyfulness.  The happy twist that transforms the wedding banquet into a sort of PG-rated orgy, through the magic of Aphrodite, did not quite have the tone of innocent nostalgia that I was looking for.  I just thought, No good can come of this; they will all be miserable tomorrow!

96l reviews!  Are you kidding me?  After the first dozen or so reviews, do the other 949 of you actually think you had something worthwhile to add?  Once any item...book, movie, CD, whatever, has a dozen or so reviews...and a range of ratings from folks with a variety of opinions about it...any more reviews are just ego-indulgence on the part of the writers.  The number of reviews that turn up on for items on amazon.com are stark staring ridiculous.

As for the movie itself, it's not great cinema...or a great movie musical...but if you don't much care if Brosnan can sing or not, and you like ABBA songs, and you're in the mood for a beautiful island and some simple fun...this is one for you.

Frankly, I was never a great fan of the music of ABBA in their heyday. However, when I was dragged to the theater to see the stage version of their songs, I was impressed. The story line and songs matched perfectly, the energy of the production was uplifting and the overall effect was joyous. And then came the movie; Meryl Streep singing? Amanda Seyfried who? The movie, though, is quite up to its Broadway beginnings, even with all the Hollywood hoopla, stunning sets and expanded scenery. The women characters are great; Meryl is better than expected and absolutely absorbed in her role, Amanda has an excellent voice and Christine Baranski and Julie Walters ham it up wonderfully. The men however, don't fare as well. Pierce Brosnan can hold a note but sounds like he tearing his throat out. Luckily, Stellan Skarsgard and Colin Firth don't have much to do. Still, it's all wonderful fun and worth watching or owning if you are a fan of musicals, Broadway or Hollywood, as I am.

Yes, it was campy.  No, Pierce Brosnan is not the best singer in the world.  But, what absolute fun!  And Meryl Streep - well I could listen to her over and over (oh, yes I did!) Although it is a brief addition at the end, for me it spoils the entire movie.  As a YHWH fearing soul,  I believe SIN is define through the TORAH.  It is NOT subject to discussion.  Either you believe in YHWH (God) or you don't.  The Messiah, YahuShua (or Jesus for those that know Him by His english nick name)  said, "If you love me, you will follow my commands".)  Those Commands are all from Torah.  Therefore, although this production has the potential to be one of the BEST musicals in modern day, for me it is ruined by unnecessary reference to sins.  Perhaps there is some idea that it will encourage more viewing, but I do not agree.

I have to laugh at all the self-righteous blowhards who came here to criticize everything about this film! Of course this is not 'Citizen Kane' or 'Gone With The Wind', and it's not meant to showcase the best there is in film-making art! This is a lighthearted, FUN musical, using ABBA's music, filmed in one of the most gloriously beautiful corners of the world (Greek Isles of Skopelos and Skiathos). The film adaptation is very well done, and the movie is pure fun and joy from beginning until end. The actors and actresses are not attempting to outsing the original artists- they are merely lending their own voices and personal feel to the great, classic ABBA songs here. To think otherwise is missing the point. Ignore the naysayers and watch it for yourselves IF you know how to have a good time, that is!

Mama Mia is the big-screen adaptation of the hit Broadway musical. Sophie lives on a remote Greek island with her ex-rock star mother Donna (Meryl Streep, who, you may know, can nail a song). Sophie is about to marry Sky and she really wants her dad to give her away. Unfortunately, Sophie doesn't know who her father is. Finding her mother's diary, she invites the three men Donna was involved with at the time: Bill (Stellan Skarsgard), Sam (Pierce Brosnan) and Harry (Colin Firth).  Mostly the film is a showcase for singing and dancing to the best of ABBA's songs.  It got a lot of critical reviews, but it definitely worked for me.  A lot of fun.
It's a cute little movie, not trying to be anything it isn't. You will love it if you are an ABBA fan.  It brought back memories of the day when ABBA was on the radio.

What if there were a movie that tackled such difficult issues as facing your past, gender norms, feminism, gay acceptance, growing old, single parenthood, economic hardship and lost love?

You wouldn't want to see it, framed that way, and neither would I -- which is reason number 100-or-so that I love this movie: It's so much fun you don't realize that yes, it DOES have a plot, and the issues are pretty dang serious.

Framed around the songs of ABBA, that's quite a challenge. ABBA, like most pop groups, wrote the same love song over and over, and here they are trying to use that one song to tell the stories of 1. A young woman searching for her biological father because she hopes this will make her whole 2. The mother facing the here-and-now of her past free spirit 3. Three men facing whether they are (or ever should be) fathers and whether they'll ever be in love again (and with whom)4. A young man deciding whether to give in to a poofy over the top wedding ceremony against his better judgement because it will make the woman he loves happy.

In the "classic" movie musicals, the sets looked like sets--you can see the backdrops pretty well in Oklahoma! and Seven Brides for Seven Brothers--so if the last time you saw a musical it was from the 40s, the real life location here may be jarring. You'll get used to it. I also was suprised--and am pretty much jumping for joy--that the extras they chose are not Hollywood models but people with average faces and figures who know how to dance. (The nice exception is the beach dancing led by Christine Baranski, and let me tell you, it so works.)

And speaking of not overdone, LOVED the singing. Pierce Brosnan is wonderful, "courageous" someone put it. He's not portraying a musician. He's portraying a man so overcome with emotion he bursts into song. Meryl Streep, whose voice is wonderful, IS portraying a singer. It so works. Their duets are touching. All the voices are just right for the parts they play.

And if it wraps up a little too cleanly for real life, do I mind? Nope, I wish it were this way.  They all live happily ever after. And that's fine with me.

The touring musical, MAMMA MIA! now becomes a musical movie. Rated "PG-13". Running Time: 1 hour, 48 mins. Sophie (Amanda Seyfried) is getting married in your birth town of Kalokairi, Greece. She wants her dad to give her away, but she doesn't know who her father is. So she invites all three men, Sam (Pierce Brosnan), Bill (Stellan Skarsgard) and Harry (Colin Firth). They think that her mother sent the invitations. She has not told her mother, Donna (Meryl Streep) yet. Also in the cast: Christine Baranski, Julie Walters, Dominic Cooper. Meryl Streep and Piecre Brosnan singing? The singing in this musical is mediocre, but you might enjoy the songs which came from the Swedish pop-rock group, ABBA (1972-83). ABBA was Benny Andersson, Anna-Frid Lyngstad, Agnetha Faltskog, Bjorn Ulvaeus. Their songs were so popular, they were used in 1999 in the touring musical, MAMMA MIA!. I did not like this movie too well, but I thought Amanda Seyfried was perfect for her role. She did a wonderful job. Option to turn on "Sing Along". Option of Language and Subtitles: English, Spanish, French. Feature Commentary with Director Phyllida Lloyd. ***Sequel: Mamma Mia! Here We Go Again! to be released July 20, 2018. With Pierce Brosnan, Meryl Streep and Cher. Meryl Streep and Cher have worked together before in Silkwood (1983). Meryl Streep also sang in Silkwood (1983). Ironweed (1987). Postcards from the Edge (1990). A Prairie Home Companion (2006). If you did not like the movie, Mamma Mia! (2008), may I recommend:  Evil Under the Sun (1982). It's a good Agatha Christie mystery. It's not a musical, I promise.

Momma Mia is one of my all time favorite movies. I love the plot; but more than that, I love the music, which seems to fit perfectly with every scene. However, I do not see the need, or understand why you felt it necessary to have Harry become a homosexual, it does not fit into the movie at all, and seems quite out of place.

First, let me preface this by saying that I enjoy Abba's music. This is basically a group of Abba songs loosely tied together with a charming storyline. Despite its relatively weak storyline, the movie is thoroughly enjoyable. I don't remember the last time I saw a movie where the actors seemed to really enjoy themselves. Kudos to the established actors for singing their songs (vs. lip synching) - particularly gorgeous Pierce Brosnan, who doesn't have the most lyrical of voices. That takes courage. By the same token, I was impressed by the musical voices of Meryl Streep and Colin Firth. The vocal talents of young Amanda Siegfried are impressive. Of course scenes of the beautiful Adriatic just add to the enjoyment, as does seeing the always handsome Colin Firth and Pierce Brosnan in the same film. So, if you want an uncomplicated movie that just leaves you feeling good - maybe singing a few Abba songs - rent this movie.

There's a lot to like in this movie. It has Amanda Seyfried looking like a younger and cuter Cameron Diaz. Then there's the chick-lit comedy that she leads (or tries to), about strange family secrets emerging on the eve of her wedding. Throw in Abba's bouncy music, likeable again now that the disco era is fading from memory. Then add Meryl Streep in a physically comedic role, with Pierce Brosnan and lots of others pulling their weight. You already know that it's going to end up OK - not just in the romantic plot, but as a movie, too. Lots more makes it work, as well. The ongoing visual gag of the "Greek chorus" never palls. A few points really stood out, like the bachelor party descending on the bachelorette party, merging them both into some neo-primitive fertility rite (clothes on, if it matters). But Streep and her co-stars really made this movie. She comes across as a strong and active, but decidedly mature character - as befits a woman whose age startled me when I looked it up on IMDB. Two other I-know-that-face actresses form a trio with her, and come from the same age group. I found it absolutely delightful to see these ladies being honest about their ages in these roles, but still as playful as schoolgirls, even to bouncing on the bed and to resurrecting their years-ago girl band to entertain Sophie's wedding eve. Maybe you have to be of the graying age to appreciate it properly, but it was great to see women of my age (and up) with exciting histories and plenty of goofy excitement in their present days, too. But, amid all these enjoyable parts, a few stand out. One was that massive dance routine to "Dancing Queen" - I laughed so hard that my eyes watered continuously the whole length of it. If you thought that the day of the musical comedy movie ended with A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum, well, you had good reason to think that. New facts just came onto the scene, though, and the musical comedy is back again, at least this once. It's howling funny. -- wiredweird
awesome movie , fast shipping , good price, no  skipping, glitches , nothing wrong with it at all , its perfect, will purchase again.

I like ABBA music, and I'm in the target demographic, but I cringed continually watching this.  There is a scene right before the wedding where Meryl Streep is singing for several minutes about how she doesn't want to talk, while Pierce Brosnan is standing there in what for him must have been an excruciating reaction shot.  But I also felt he was thinking: "This is dreadful.  Thank heavens we're filming at a great location and tonight we can get drunk at the taverna in town."  The acting seems forced and phony, and I could not identify with anyone in the movie.  The idea that a young woman would somehow think it romantic (which is what the bride-to-be expresses in her opening song) that her mother had sex with three different men in succession strains credulity.  The giggling didn't help.  Ouch. Ouch. Ouch.
Good one to sing along to with the kids.  Very enjoyable to watch especially in the car rides we take.  It is an everybody movie for all ages.
New, in plastic wrapping, like I'd just bought it at the store when it first came out.  It was in new condition and timely shipping.  Thank you.

What's not to love? Here's the music of my childhood, my favorite stars, and a truly delightful love story. This takes me back to some of the happiest times of my life, and I'm ecstatic. Two big thumbs up, and five bright, gleaming stars!

Pure delight!  Some of the most beautiful scenery I've ever seen, makes me want to go there.  Pierce Brosnan's singing is a little flat at times, but he's always lovely to look at.  Christine Baranski has always been a favorite of mine, a great Broadway pro.  What an angelic voice and beautiful face Amanda Seyfried has. Everyone else is perfect and fun especially the dash of Julie Walters.  The whole movie is joyous.  I also own the CD and again love the words to a lot of the songs, I can remember the visuals of the movie as I'm hearing them while I'm sewing, especially "Does Your Mother Know."  Good family fun.

It's really quite simple: if you're a huge ABBA fan, you're going to love this movie.  If not (I fall into this category), the movie will be torture to watch.

The only reason this musical and movie have such a strong following is that ABBA has a fanbase of baby-boomers that love their music.  Those fans, watching this movie, love the music so much that they are blind to the shallow characters, flimsy plot, and all of the forced, unrealistic scenes.  I had always thought it was backwards and just plain wrong to write a story based on the music of a band.  These fears were confirmed when my eyes witnessed this film.

As a theater major and actor, I have seen countless plays, musicals, and movies, so don't discredit my review and think that I don't know a musical is indended to be campy and corny.  The issues I had with this film had nothing to do with the corniness.  I will hear people say that they can tell the actors were having fun while filming the movie.  Unfortunately, that does nothing for me as the viewer.  Find a Jr. High with a lousy theater program doing "Grease."  They too are "having fun."

It's possible that my review would be different if the band involved were AC/DC or Paul Simon, but until that movie gets made, I feel I must warn the world that there are better ways to spend your time.

Mamma Mia in Blu-ray is breath-taking, scenery is great, sound is second to none. ABBA music is timeless. Pierce Brosnan is a great actor, but should not consider a career in singing. All-in-All this is a wonderful musical
After seeing the live play I had to get the movie I wasn't disappointed. All star cast, a fun movie to watch.

Okay, let me be honest. I had heard about this film/musical for a long time. I thought I'd give it a shot because I like ABBA songs and a good musical. Sadly this film had a stupid plot meant to try and fit in the various ABBA songs they wanted to feature.

I won't comment on the singing which ranges from wonderful to terrible. Bravo for trying and you will also be surprised at who can sing in this film.

I found myself saying, 'Who cares?' most of the movie. I watched it on dvd and fast forwarded most of the second half.

The best songs were at the end of the movie in the wrap up scenes. What were they thinking? Put them in the movie, not at the end when people are walking out.

I think I was just confused at the muddled plot. Very stupid, stupid idea for a movie.
It was a really good movie, the actors that were cast in the movies really made the movie a great watch and I would have my friends purchase it.
This movie is funny, sad, exciting all wrapped up in one.  Especially fun with a room full of women! Great for all ages!  Kids too!

This is a wonderful "time out" from the frenzy of daily living.  Just load your dixc palyer, put your feet up and enjoy.  It will be difficult to stay seated though, as the tunes are very infectious.  My friend and I found ourselves singing along, using a hair brush as a microphone, and laughing ourselves until our sides ached.  So, suspend reality and enjoy.
This is a really good show.  All the actors and actresses are terrific.  I love the music and it is a lot of fun. I really enjoy it every time I watch it. So do my friends.
Movie was still in original packing, price was super. Very good buy will look for more DVD's especially the older ones.

(+) it was shipped fast.
(+) it was shipped in an envelope with bubble wrap lining in it. content was great.
(-) it wasn't a blue ray official case (the blue kind). It was a black dvd case, with the mamma-mia cover. Since it was for a gift, I was saddened by that.

Overall good review. I'll read more specifically next time what kind of case it'll come in. If not specified, I'd ask first. :o)

The movie has some slow songs in the musical at times, but if you like Abba songs, and the Greek Isles in a crisp blueray picture, paying extra for this movie in a blueray format won't dissapoint you. Great effort was also made to insure the extras in this BD were also blueray quality which many times the studios skimp on, and this BD is full of extras. Enjoy.
This is an utterly stupid movie that completely wastes Meryl Streep's phenomenal acting power. The nicest part of this movie was the ocean in the background....

It is a fun, uplifting movie. If you are a baby boomer it has special significance. If you are younger, well you can have a good time learning a bit about what it was like to be one and the child of one. I LIKE IT !  ...Oscar
We just keep watching this one.

The 80s died for a reason. They should stay dead. This revival? SLIGHTLY less horrifying than the Yellow Submarine. The main character was a manipulative, wishy-washy bitch (and why was and Streep the only ones with an American accent?) The plot... who am I kidding? WHAT plot? At least MOST musicals make SOME sort of cohesive sense! I'm not entirely certain WHY I watched the entire thing, other than it was the soul-destroying train-wreck that, once you start watching, you have to finish.

You cannot beat ABBA music.  The actors did a good job
of it.  Props for stepping out of their comfort zone.
Meryl was especially good, though the movie did drag occasionally.

I said it once and I probably would say it until I die, I love ABBA music, I find it infinitely charming. I don't know how this happened, I wasn't born in their decade, my dad didn't play their music as much when I was growing up, none of my musician friends or music idols consider ABBA as one of their inspirations yet I do. And just like I appreciate their music when no one in my social circle does I enjoy this movie thoroughly when not even my fiancee does. Its corny, simplistic, predictable, and has an unrealistic sparkling brightness that makes romantic comedies like "The Sweetest Thing" look like serious gritty mysteries. But it's not all fluff, we do have Meryl Streep who has the ability to make the Titanic resurface with her bigger than life characters. Maybe is the fact that the actors spent more time singing/dancing than acting that I felt I was watching a music video. Maybe is the beautiful Greek scenery that brings me back to my youngest dreams of paradise. Maybe I'm just cheesy like that...but this movie is charming, harmless and even though it has enough sugar to make you diabetic, you might just like me, like it. It is definitely a strange zone you step in when you find yourself idiotically singing along to a movie while your fiancee looks at you and says "That's just gay"

I like this movie, but the one thing that I can't figure out is what is a Digital Copy; I have tried to play it in both the Regular AND the Blue-Ray DVD Players and it Doesn't even work, so I haven't a clue to why the Manufactoring Companies insist on putting something in when it doesn't even work.  If and only if it's meant for the Computer, then why don't these Manufacting Companies say that its for the Computer.  I HATE Guessing Games, and these Manufactoing Companies insist on playing Guessing Games with people that know Practiclly Nothing when it comes to such things as a Digital Copy of Any Movie.  If these editodic Fool Harded Companies are going to insist in putting these Digital Copies in with Movies, then in my own Opinion, I would have to say that these Companies / Business's MUST also Include Instrctions in just how Exactley these Digital Copies are to Work and are to be Played!  But will these Compnaies / Business's Include Extreamly Simplafied Instructions in how to go about the Playing of these DIgital Copies, NO they Won't, so why are they Waisting Everyone's Time and Money by Including a Digital Copy of some Movies, when a Percentage { % } of the Worlds Population is 100 % Clueless in how these Digital Copies Work and are to be Played?
  So what I do with ALL Digital Copies of any movie that I get, I Shreed it Up in my Shreeder, for the reason's because One { 1 } it doesn't work, and secondly { 2ndly } I haven't any ideaa to how it is supposed to be played!  So why should I go waisting Money and Space for something that I haven't any idea to how it is to be played AND how it works.

I have seen the theatrical production 4 times and the movie once.  The movie was terrible!  The movie cut songs that were in the play and destroyed the continuity of the music and story.  Pierce Brosnan might be eye candy, but he can't sing and looked uncomfortable.  Worst of all was the direction by Phyllida Lloyd.  I cannot fault the actors and production for her inability to make the show go.  I recently had the misfortune of seeing a theatrical production of this show directed by Ms Lloyd.  Her version chopped up the music and interrupted beautiful songs with inane conversation.  It was painful to try to sit through this movie.

This movie revolves around love, a universal subject. Terrific songs from Abba. My favourite song in the film is Our Last Summer. It's wonderful that Amanda's character has three potential fathers. Wonderful story, wonderful music, and wonderful actors/actresses, but it's not a 5-star film.

The GOOD

- Wow! The music is lovely. It also inspires me to dance. It sounds exactly like the original played by ABBA.

- The scenes are beautiful with the sea, mountain, beach, sunshine and houses on the mountain.

- There are many hilarious scenes too. For instance, Meryl Streep was carried away while singing Mama Mia and fell through a hole. Another is where an older lady flirted with a younger, brown guy. One more is where multiple guys dancing on the pier with their diving fins.

- Out of 18 songs in this movie, I love 13 of them. They are: Honey Honey, Money, Mama Mia, Chiquitita, Dancing Queen, Lay All Your Love on Me, Super Trouper, Vouler Vous, SOS, The Winner Takes It All, When All Is Said and Done, Take a Chance on Me, I Have a Dream.

- According to boxofficemojo dot com, its production Budget was $52 million.
Domestic gross:  $144,130,063
+ Foreign gross  $465,711,574
= Worldwide gross $609,841,637

So it's profit was more than 10 times its cost.

The NOT SO GOOD

- Some of the songs are incomplete or interrupted with dialogues. This is really annoying because I need to listen to the whole song to completely enjoy it. For example, in the scene of Chiquitita song, the last sentence was omitted. It's replaced with the dialogues between Meryl Streep and her two girlfriends. The director should have the song completely sung before continuing with the actors' conversation.
Another is in the scene of Gimme Gimme song. It is broken into 3 pieces by the actors' conversation. That makes it much less enjoyable.

- It does not have Karaoke version. That means there's no scene with only instrumental music. So, you have to sing along. You can't sing  Karaoke.

- Of course, it's a musical film, so, please don't expect any logic and character development.

Well, nothing is perfect. In short, every Karaoke fan or person who loves singing should have one copy. I'm singing along and dancing with this DVD once a month now. It's an excellent showcase of  timeless songs.
This was a great feel good movie, I do not always like musicals yet this one was so much fun, a funny story line, lots of humor and the sound track just lovely with a lot of dancing. Just love it.
Mamma Mia is a very good musical and the actors did a good job.  Love it and will watch it many times!
The Girls around this house love to watch this and sometimes to sing along! I'm not much on musicals but this is engaging fun.

I love this film - I got hooked the first time I watched it on regular DVD and must say it's my next best favorite (my favorite being Mary Poppins.)  I really do like musicals and this one is great.  I like all the extras on the Blu-ray. Information I would normally had to look up on a search engine. I do have to say I didn't notice a whole lot of difference in quality from the DVD and the Blu-ray after watching both on a Blu-ray machine, which is why I give it 4 stars not 5.

My purchase of Mama Mia, in full screen format on DVD was the best purchase I have made all year. The picture quality is perfect, and the sound is amazing. I enjoyed it tremendously, right up until my 11 year old Granddaughter came to visit and watched it with me. When she left two days later it went with her. Her Mother has informed me she watches it every day and is driving her insane with it. Thanks to the feature showing the words to the songs, when my Granddaughter is not watching the DVD, she is singing the songs. All in all justifying it as the best purchase I have made all year. Thanks Amazon!!!!!

Since I was young I have used music to sustain me emotionally and psychologically.
I remember listening to Beethoven's Third Symphony (Eroica) and Dvorak's New World Symphony when I was feeling down or stressed.  The music would lift me and help me go on.  Recently I discovered that Mamma Mia performs a similar service.

Mamma Mia is an excellent musical.  I remember the musicals of the 1940, 50 and 60s.  Often they had as much dialogue as singing.  Mamma Mia is almost continual singing, and the singing is cheerful and strong.  The music lifts my mood.

Meryl Streep stars and sings up a storm.  I have enjoyed Meryl in so many movies and admire her talent.  Her talent, demonstrated in such varied work as  Sophie's Choice Kramer vs. Kramer and The Devil Wears Prada, did not prepare me for her performance as Donna in Mamma Mia.  Not only is she outstanding in her role, she  sings well.

Several other actors are excellent in their roles.  Amanda Seyfried is brilliant as Donna's daughter Sophie.  Christine Baranski (recently in The Good Wife) and Julie Walters (Famous as Molly Weasley in Harry Potter films), are superior as Donna's best friends and former singing partners.

Colin Firth (Oscar for King's Speech) plays one of Donna's former lovers.  His singing is great and his guitar playing is impressive.

The biggest surprise for me was Pierce Brosnan (James Bond 007) in the role of Donna's first lover.  Pierce can not sing nearly as well as the other actors but somehow we do not mind.  He is perfect as Donna's love interest.

Mamma Mia is an entertaining film with a wonderful musical score.  I highly recommend this movie for a very pleasant evening.

Listening to Pierce Brosnan (and to a lesser extent Meryl Streep) sing in this movie is an uncomfortable experience (especially in surround sound).  That being said, the daughter in this movie (played by Amanda Seyfried) has an outstanding voice, and as a relative unknown in the movie industry, she pretty much carried the entire movie on her shoulders (musically speaking).  Somebody however, forgot to tell the producers that this movie "is a MUSICAL!". So rather than attempt generate box-office revenues from the reputation of high profile actors with bad voices (Streep, Brosnan, Firth), they would have been better off casting actors who can actually act AND SING; doing so may have made this movie as enjoyable (and as profitable) as the stage play.

Sadly Mamma Mia is not worth watching, but if you must see it, rent -- don't purchase.
I love this movie, I watch it every week. I know all the lines, songs everything! It is very addictive watching. Everyone is well cast.

There are a few movies I can watch over and over again...this is definitely one of them!  Meryl Streep is outstanding and amazing as is the rest of the cast.
Buy it, watch it, then watch it again and again and again!
I first saw this on TV and could not wait to get it on DVD. The music is amazing and the whole movie makes you feel happy and wonderful. I LOVE-LOVE-LOVE IT!

This movie is a train wreck. The only one who can carry a tune is the actress that plays the daughter. I don't know how this made it to the public, anyone watching the dailies could have told you it stinks. The story was terrible, the camera work was worse & the actors except where noted above cannot carry a tune. It was like watching 2 hours of Jr. high bad music. I can't figure out why so many people love this movie. I'd rather have a toothache than watch it again!
