DVD even better. ORDER IT TODAY!

Love it! Since it is the flower-children era, the amount of sex-related humor is inappropriate for children, but otherwise a great movie. Can't get enough of the music, and it's a trip to see Pierce and Meryl singing together!
This is the most wonderful feel good musical I've seen. I do enjoy the movie each time as if it is the first time.
Mama Mia is a great invention of arranging ABBA music into a story. The result is a movie  that will make you smile as much as Chicago.
This is a feel good movie. It makes a wonderful antidepressant. After you watch it, you can not be sad.
Video was new and just as was purchased took WAY too long to get, not impressed. Products shipped thru Amazon were way faster.

Love the movie and the music CD. Wish the movie would have been in full screen though. With the wide screen everything shows so small, even on a large screen. But overall really glad I got it. Meryl Streep is a riot. As long as you like ABBA music, I'd recommend this.
We were very satisfied with the purchase price of the dvd and the quickness of the delivery. I would not hesitant to order more products from this site.
The critics said this was not a good movie. I think they should have the heads exammined. I like it so much I bought the DVD and have watched it at least 10 times already.

This is a musical first and foremost, make no mistake; it has beautiful scenery, an amusing story line, and lots of music and dancing. If you're into that sort of thing this may well be one you'll like.

I would suggest you rent it before buying as it falls into a distinct genre of movie. Several younger members of our family recommended it to us and we watched it and found ourselves fast forwarding through a lot of the songs. I'll admit they did enjoy it so you may well enjoy it too; just watch it first and get a feel for what you would be buying.

The talent, pure talent from souls whom were actors not vocalists-Total entertainment, joy and fun. Thank You. Meryl was well Meryl,completely. Abba, family fun, great story,just makes you feel alive. Singing when you don't feel like it because life has taken over. Disney and there is finally a MOM. A classic.

But guess what? I was wrong again...this seems to happen a lot with me.  Anyway, on to the movie review...I probably would have never watched this film if it hadn't been for the persuading by my 8 year old daughter.  So I reluctantly watched it and fell in love!  I never thought I was a musical fan, but I now relaize that there is absolutely no basis for me to be labeled as such, as I now admittedly, realize that I like quite a few...there's really only a couple I can think of that I dislike.  Mamma Mia! is not one of them.  I LOVE IT!  Some of the singing is not the greatest, but it is still a fantastic movie, and anything with Meryl Streep and Colin Firth in it can call me a fan, pretty much.  It's definitely a chick flick, so I don't imagine many straight male counterparts will be lining up to see this one.  It's fun, funny, romantic, heartwarming, and the music is fantastic!  I highly recommend this one and can't wait to see the stage performance someday.  5 stars!

this movie was great my wife and i have the cd sound track too, we listen and watch them all the time.
scott dawson

if you don't have them get them.

I like good chick flicks that critics pan. I just like a good fun romantic story, I can't help it. So I expected to like this movie but I was disappointed. If I had seen it in the theaters instead of at home on my DVR and couldn't fast-forward through most of the songs like I did, I probably would have impaled myself on my soda straw.

The songs are way too numerous and often don't fit with the story. It's like they had a checklist of ABBA songs they wanted to cram in this thing so they just stuck them in as often as possible no matter what. At the end of the movie, there are four in a row, count 'em, FOUR songs, with about two lines of dialogue in there. They just roll them off just 'cause. To be fair, most of the singing was pretty good (except for Pierce Brosnan, bless his heart for trying), and it helped when they piped in ABBA-sounding background vocals to all but cover up the movie star who was trying to sing lead, but I just couldn't take one more scene watching Meryl Streep flail and roll around the set in rolled-up overalls. To be fair again, she's not a singer so she didn't know what to do with herself while singing except said jumping around, plus some head-scratching gesticulations, but it was painful to watch regardless.

The female characters were ridiculous. If you go by Sophie and her friends, or Donna and her friends, all women scream and do some ridiculous show tune or secret girl club handshake of some kind when we reunite after having been apart; and we engage in over-dramatic Ya-Ya-esque behavior the rest of the time. One scene with the mom and her friends sounded literally like hens, they were doing so much whooping and weirdness. I found it embarrassing and unflattering to our gender. I know no females (no human beings really) who act like this or who would want friends who do. Why does Hollywood do it?

I watched the whole thing mainly out of curiosity, and stubbornness because I'd be darned if I'd invested an hour of my life into this thing without seeing the end. I liked most of the characters, sure, but they were mostly amusing circus-types and not people I cared about. We didn't have time to connect with them because instead of going into character development, they were forever singing something instead, and the song rarely lent itself to the story.

That said, if you like the following:

*Watching movie stars do mediocre karaoke covers of ABBA songs every couple minutes.
*Women who whoop and holler and do lots of girl bonding over alcohol and sing encouraging songs to each other over (and under) the bathroom stall door.
*Seeing old women sing in sparkly 1970s jumpsuits and platform boots to pretend they're the disco version of the Supremes.
*Greek scenery.
*Fake old photos of Pierce Brosnan and Colin Firth elaborately dressed as hippies.
*Seeing old people kiss a lot.

...then you will really enjoy this movie.

Right, so given that list, I did not much enjoy this movie. It seems like it was way more fun for the people to make the movie than for the rest of us to watch it. At least I sure hope it was, or else all those poor people were pretty miserable that whole time. If you want an indulgent-fun chick flick, go watch Leap Year instead.

I don't really care what critics say.  This Movie is so much fun and beautifully done it is a hit in my book.  I am a big fan of all musicals and this one is one of the best.  I have seen it again on TV recently and was signing and dancing my butt off.  Have fun buy this movie.  You will not be sorry!

I saw this movie on TV and loved it so much I went out & bought it. it is afun movie that made me laugh when I needed a good laugh! I love the songs, ABBA 's songs are great and this movie put even more meaning into them. As for Pierce Brosnan's singing ...it wasn't very good, just OK, but it actually made the movie a bit more real if you let yourself get caught up in the story. Not everyone can have a great voice, but the point of the movie was to be fun, entertaining and it made me laugh.  So in this movie he was just an ordinary man in the story singing his feelings, but the rest of the cast singing was great, so for his one song...who cares?... he acted out the movie well. I will watch it again & again...I just wish I had gotten it on Amazon as it costs me about $5 more for it locally. I have seen it twice & look forward to seeing it again & again as a fun, feel good musical with an outstanding cast. Whenever, I need a pick me up I will watch this movie as I find myself singing the songs for a few days after seeing it and it makes me feel good...what more can you ask of a movie. Laughter they say is the best medicine and music makes you feel emotion. So if anyone out there is looking to buy this movie & you want something you'll enjoy,and want to get lost in the fun & joy of it and even if you never heard ABBA songs, you'll want to get this movie.

I ignored this film when it came out in theaters; just didn't interest me.  I vaguely wondered why an actress of Meryl Streep's caliber would stoop to take such a silly role.

Then one frozen day I made it out of my house to the library and picked up some DVD's to help me make it through the week.  After several sub-zero nights and frozen pipes I was in the mood for something that looked warm and sunny.  The picture on the cover of the DVD was ridiculous but at least they appeared to be dancing on a beach in front of blue water.

Wow!  It didn't take long for the warmth in this film to melt my mid-winter depression.  I didn't see the stage version so I wasn't handicapped by making that comparison.  And I never liked ABBA so I didn't care if anyone mangled their songs.

I admit that I had soured on Meryl Streep, after having been a major fan.  She seemed to have become so mannered and self conscious that I lost interest in her.  But here....another WOW!
This and her performance as Julia Child have reinstated her into my personal fan club.  She is just so filled with life!  If anyone is willing to suspend belief in the credibility of the script, and just go along with the sheer exuberance of the film, they can have a great time.

True, there are lots of "flaws" for the serious film goer which is probaly why critics didn't like it.  Besides a silly story, the casting is somewhat strange, especially the three men.  Colin Firth, whom I adored in so many roles, is awkward and looks embarrased for most of the film.  But that is his character!  And I give him credit for putting himself in such an embarrasing position.

Pierce Brosnan is good as the aging cute guy who can't sing but gives it a try.  He is losing his looks but that's good for the role, too.  He's just a guy who made a mistake and has paid for it and now is getting another chance.  The Swedish fellow seemed well cast.

Amanda Seyfried was perfect as the prettiest little gumdrop of a girl you'd ever want to see in a movie.  She was more than a pretty face, too, she acted very well.  The scene where Streep prepares her for her wedding brought tears to my eyes.  Christine Baranski, an actress I never liked, was terrific here.  I loved the bit where she has an almost-romance with an adorable young Black barboy.  Julie Walters was terrific, too.  I was glad to see that each of them had a chance to shine.  The numbers with the three of them performing were wonderful!  So much energy, so much joy!

I can see now why Streep and the rest chose to make this less-than-Oscar-worthy film---for the sheer fun of it!  It really comes across.  A really good time awaits anyone who can open up to sheer, mindless enjoyment.  Intellectual snobs better pass.
I loved this movie when I saw it in theaters & recently saw the musical on stage. It definitely has you singing & dancing in your seat. I could watch it over & over.

One of the most Excellent movies for all ages. The acting was just superlative. One of the best movies of this day for all age groups.
 The scenery was breathtaking.
 A movie is supposed to be entertainment, this was above and beyond.
 Pierce Brosnan was one of the most heart felt singers plus exceptional acting and chemistry with Meryl Streep. The people at the "RAZZLE"
 awards should be ashamed!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
 His singing would be received by Donna as extremely romantic. The four actresses were also, excellent.
 The  bachelors and her young man also made for a heartwarming  Musical ...

This is not a movie for people  who are looking for a deep, thought provoking two hours.  It's for people who are looking for fun, pure fun.  It's also for people who are Meryl Streep fans.  It's obvious how much fun these A List actors are having with this material.  I read somewhere that Colin Firth has said this movie was the most fun he ever had making a movie.  The only reason I wouldn't give it 5 stars is because it is a bit jarring when the songs don't quite fit the situation.  It's obvious that the plot was written around the songs.  Musicals work best when the songs are written around the plot.  But these are some truly inventive, playful and joyful tunes and the choreography is fresh and energetic.  It's just for fun A One!
This movie is exactly what it's supposed to be:  refreshing, relaxing, escapism.  I loved the singing, especially the 'quirky' voices.
I loved this movie, and have seen it a couple times,  all the actors were fantastic and the ending was hysterical I liked the fact they spoke to the audience  GREAT
The movie is fine, arrived on time as described, not my cup of tea. Nothing blowing up, no cars chases, not blood and guts, you know.

I ordered Wed pm and it was waiting for me when i got home Thursday - less than 12 hours - how can that be - I was thrilled = I know I will love it as I have seen before and had to have my own copy.  WOW Amazon you said 2days with Prime and it was not even one whole day - you are Amazing with shipping and customer service. it is a GREAT movie - saw on Broadway last week and just had to have it to continue singing.

The movie is a 'feel good'/ hey I recognize that face! experience.  It doesn't drag and is not predictable or trite.  Once again, Meryl Streep morphs into a role that fits her like a second skin.  You vacilate between identifying with the younger generation and then the older generation and its a great feeling.  Watch this with anyone!  Your kids, spouse, youth group, whoever. Movie came immediately as described.  It is a Christmas gift so it has not been opened or viewed yet.

I absolutely loved the movie! My two daughters three and five were watching with me one day and they fell in love with the music and dancing. They like the movie so much I took them to NYC to see the play on broadway. I personally like the movie better than the play. My children listen to the soundtrack and always want to watch the movie. The movie is great.  But the BluRay DVD is poor quality.  The audio is fine, it's just that the color is often distorted; not HD.  I recommend NOT buying this version of the BluRay at this time.  I suggest one should wait a while, six months or so, for the producers to get the bugs out of their process.  This review is based upon having received a second (replacement) disc from Amazon for the same problem.  Too bad.  I would ask for another replacement, but I am confident it wouldn't be any better.

I've never been a fan of the ABBA singers (My husband is an avid fan.) so I wasn't really interested when my granddaughter rented it for the two of us to have a night at the (home) movies, popcorn in hand.  What a surprise!  Lighthearted fun and excitement among the players, music and dancing that uplifts you in spite of yourself.  The writers did a fantastic job of fitting all those songs to the story...or did they write the story to fit the songs?  The ABBA music is really the driving force throughout the movie...or is the story the driving force?  Hard to tell...
Most of the actors did a great job singing and dancing and the story is clean and enjoyable.  I read an interview in which Pierce Brosnen stated that he'd never sang in his life and his singing is proof enough. Even his singing grows on you after a few viewings.  I enjoyed the movie so much I had to order it from Amazon!  Perhaps the cast was not made up of trained singers, but any deficiencies were covered by their super star performances.  Now my 3 and 5 year old grandchildren want me to play it every time they're here.  I even listen to it when  working at the computer or in the kitchen.  I have so much music in the house (I'm a classical piano teacher with degrees in music.) yet, I find this rendition of ABBA's music and the gaiety of the story the most contagious I've heard or seen in years.  In this time of so many trashy songs and movies this is a real family treat.

First, I agree with what Jim "Firefighter" wrote! This is simply a feel good movie from the opening of it till the end of it. I say that and I'm certainly not even a Meryl Streep fan in the least. Still, she proved perfect for the part. As for Bronson not being able to sing that well, that just added to the fun experience! PERFECT!

This movie is about SMILES and FUN and that is exactly what you get in SPADES!!! It doesn't matter if it comes off a little cheesy at times, and as one reviewer said, a little like a third tier production, that just adds color and flavor to it!

For viewers who don't like musicals this movie will not appeal to you either. In my view, you either like musicals or you don't. For the borderline few who aren't sure whether they like musicals or not...this might be the one you want to choose to settle the matter once and for all.

To repeat...THIS IS A FUN MOVIE and no critics view is going to change that! The matter has been settled and the critics LOSE, and the viewer WINS! AMEN!!!!

I thought a movie with all ABBA songs What???  I own this movie and it's the most watched movie in my house. It is the best feel good movie since John Wayne in Mclintock. As a music major, Pierce was pretty good for a novice and trying to "show" emotion in his singing. Critics don't know crap. They must have had a blast making this movie. As far as the director she was just interested in making a good movie. Oh and did anyone know Tom Hanks helped produce this movie. Great movie!

If you loved this play, you will truly be disappointed in the quality of the acting and singing in this movie.  It was laughable at times.  Very Hard to watch and painful to see Pierce Brosnon singing.  It just does not work for a movie.

A great movie that you can watch over and over and it never gets old!
Great cast! The movie came quick and in great condition!
Very Happy!

Mamma Mia picks you up and almost forces you to smile, laugh, and have fun.  Whether watching it at home with your significant other and a bottle of wine; on an airplane next to some of your closest friends you've never met; by yourself with some tequila; or with a good friend who likes to sing with you, this movie fits for nearly everyone.  Meryl Streep is fabulous.  She bounds, bounces, bellows, sings, and rolls into your heart.  She had so much fun making the movie and it shows.  Her up tempo performance transports you on stage with her.
Pierce Brosnan's horrendous singing brings more mirth and merryment to the experience.  He acts like someone much younger and revels in his inability to sing.  When watching this movie again recently with a friend, we couldn't help but laugh when his character went over the top to try to impress Ms. Streep.
Amanda Seyfried has an amazing voice, especially for someone so young.
And when Ms. Streep and her two friends come out to sing their biggest number, you are going to want to stand up and dance with them.
Yes, it helps if you enjoy Abba music.  You should at least be slightly familiar with some of their biggest hits.  And don't go into it thinking this will be your typical Meryl Streep Oscar-winning, serious role.  This movie is all about having fun.  Hell, if more of us tried to incorporate Abba or other catchy music into our daily lives, we would probably be much happier and laid-back.
So kick back, grab a beverage, cuddle up with your wife or girlfriend -- or watch it by yourself if you want to keep it as your guilty pleasure -- and get ready to launch into a rowdy time.

This review could also be titled, "Honey honey, how it thrilled me, uh huh, honey honey!"  Or "Gimme Gimme Gimme some more Mamma Mia."  Thank god I'm not that corny.

This is BY FAR the dumbest musical ever made. And musicals are not exactly 'food for tought', if you know what I mean.

Watchig Merryl Streep plugging power tools for intimate pleasure alone is worth the price of the package. Listening to Pierce Brosnan sing... priceless.

A great musical to have on Blu-ray, the quality is amazing and you get the sing along bonus :-). Is one of those movies that lifts your spirit with no effort and leaves you with a big smile and wanting for more. Except for Brosnan, the actor's singing will not disappoint you. And what else you can say about Meryl Streep: she is just a GENIUS of this craft! 100% lovely.
Fun movie with lots of music from  Abba. Scenery was awesome. Storyline was great.

Mama Mia is sure to become a classic musical.  It's fun and romantic.  The musical scores and dance routines are outstanding.  My 11 and 15-year olds are still singing songs around the house from the movie.

As I said earlier, the movie its self as well as the music of ABBA rocked, I was saddened by the fact I ordered widescreen and got full screen instead.  I want to see the whole picture not parts of it
I love this movie! My children watch it in the car all the time! They have seen it already 30 times at least! The know the lyrics of all songs and love to sing along! Great family film!

Really enjoyed the film. Alot of dancing and alot of Great music! Abba is sung by the actors and actresses themselves and they did an amazing job. The film gives a feel of realism and a feel of being on vacation. You truly feel that you are part of the film. It's a must on anyones shopping list!

Tacky, corny, and very silly. But so much fun! And the music? Loved it. No they're not all singers but they're great. The scenary is spectacular, the music contagious, and the theme...... This is a fell good movie that is very close to home for those of free spirits of the 60's.

For a (guy) and gal who grew up on Mary Poppin's, Sound of Music and the song of Norway and other singing Classic's of the forty's fifty's and sixty's. It has been a long time since we have heard a great movie that was a musical.

Being a fan of ABBA, I was looking forward to seeing the movie. However, I found the pacing of the movie incredibly slow compared to the stage play. It was, in a word, boring. To add to the disappointment, the leads (Streep and Brosnan) were not up to the vocal requirements of the score (especially Brosnan). While I enjoy them as actors, they needed to have their voices dubbed or at least their performances improved.
The other disappointment was the change of the script towards the end adding the reference about families being of all types. That was not in the original as I remember. That could have been left out. Also, the producers could have left off the tacky ending with the cast parading around in those horrid suits. True, the stage play has that addition but it comes off much better on stage than on screen.

If you are a fan of the stage play, I believe you will be disappointed with this version.

I have always loved Abba and this movie truly does it justice.  I watch it over and over again and other movies as well, but really like this movie an the scenery is so awesome.  The actors did such a wonderful job.

I don't remember much about it but I do remember that the acting WAS rather poor. As for the singing, many who gave this movie a 1 star review mentioned how terrible the singing was. I for one found the singing actually pretty good. Some of it was pretty ear wrenching but for the most part I can't complain. I know nothing of directing so I can't say anything about that.

It's the only way for us to get through that drudgery!  There really is no better way to lift your mood than to watch a musical. "Mamma Mia! The Movie", the film adaptation from the jukebox musical by British playwright Catherine Johnson and featuring the songs of ABBA, composed by Benny Anderson and Bjorn Ulvaeus (both the male members of the group).  In 1999, the musical has brought in over $2.0 billion in earnings (becoming the highest grossing musical of all time)and what better than to have a film adaptation a decade later.

With Tom Hanks and wife Rita Wilson producing the film, "Mamma Mia! The Movie" would be directed by British director Phyllida Lloyd and a screenplay by Catherine Johnson.  The film adaptation would feature an all-star cast starring Meryl Streep ("Kramer vs. Kramer", "Adaptation", "The Devil Wears Prada"), Pierce Brosnan (James Bond 007 films, "The Thomas Crown Affair"), Colin Firth ("The English Patient", "Pride and Prejudice", "Shakespeare in Love"), Stellan Skarsgard ("Pirates of the Carribean: At World's End", "Beowulf and Grendel", "Dogville), Julie Walters (Harry Potter films, "Becoming Jane", "Billy Elliot) and Christine Baranski ("Happy Family", "How the Grinch Stole Christmas", "Chicago") and a film that would jumpstart the careers of Amanda Seyfried ("Mean Girls", "Veronica Mars") and Dominic Cooper ("The Duchess").

The film which cost $52 million would earn over $609 million worldwide in the box office making the film one of the top 50 highest grossing films of all time and the distinction of the highest grossing movie musical in the world.

"Mamma Mia! The Movie" showcases the music of ABBA and features all main talent taking part in singing of the songs.  Included are:

1. "I Have A Dream" - Sophie
2. "Honey, Honey" - Sophie, Ali, and Lisa
3. "Money, Money, Money" - Donna, Tanya, Rosie, and Greek Chorus
4. "Mamma Mia" - Donna, Sophie, Ali, Lisa, and Greek Chorus
5. "Chiquitita" - Rosie, Tanya, and Donna
6. "Dancing Queen" - Tanya, Rosie, Donna, Greek Chorus, and Company
7. "Our Last Summer" - Harry, Bill, Sam, Sophie, and Donna
8. "Lay All Your Love on Me" - Sky, Sophie, Sky's Bachelor party friends.
9. "Super Trouper" - Donna, Tanya, and Rosie
10. "Gimme! Gimme! Gimme! (A Man After Midnight)" - Sophie, Donna, Tanya, Rosie, Ali, Lisa and Greek Chorus
11. "The Name of the Game" - Sophie (deleted scene)
12. "Voulez-Vous " - Donna, Sam, Tanya, Rosie, Harry, Bill, Sky, Ali, Lisa, and Pepper
13. "SOS" - Sam, Donna, and Greek Chorus
14. "Does Your Mother Know" - Tanya, Pepper, Guys, and Girls
15. "Slipping Through My Fingers" - Donna and Sophie
16. "The Winner Takes It All" - Donna
17. "I Do, I Do, I Do, I Do, I Do" - Sam, Donna, and Company
18. "When All Is Said and Done" - Sam, Donna, and Company
19. "Take a Chance on Me" - Rosie, Bill, Tanya, Pepper, and Harry
20. "Mamma Mia!" (Reprise) - Company
21. "I Have A Dream" (Reprise) - Sophie, Westlife and Company
22. "Dancing Queen" (Reprise) - Donna, Rosie, and Tanya
23. "Waterloo" - Donna, Rosie, Tanya, Sam, Bill, Harry, Sky, and Sophie
24. "Thank You for the Music" - Sophie

VIDEO:

"Mamma Mia! The Movie" is presented in 1080p High-Definition (Widescreen 2:40:1).  "Mama Mia! The Movie" is quite interesting presentation.  For one, the film is shot in Greece and the scenery is absolutely breathtaking.  But there is also an artistic element that cinematographer Haris Zambarloukos brought to the film (Director Phyllida Lloyd goes more into wanting a dramatical effect for the film through experimental shooting during day and night).  From scenes overlooking the ocean at night with the beautiful black and blues, to the shots of the wedding as lights are seen going up to the church area.  Absolute beautiful!

But it's also important to note that Zambarloukos went with colors that are high in contrast at times and colors that may seem a bit oversaturated  at times but for the most part, it added to the vibrancy of the film  and looks incredible on Blu-ray.

AUDIO & SUBTITLES:

"Mamma Mia! The Movie" is presented in English DTS-HD Master Audio and Spanish and French Dolby Digital 5.1.  Dialogue is clear and understandable and comes clear from the front and center channels but the film is obviously going to be musically driven and one is not going to hear an aggressive soundtrack.  Music sounds good but not great as the lossless soundtrack is not as immersive as I would have wanted it to be.  I didn't notice the surround or rear channels being utilized throughout the film.  So, it would have been great if the mix would have incorporated those channels.

SPECIAL FEATURES:

"Mamma Mia! The Movie" comes with the following special features:

  *
  * The Making of Mamma Mia! - (24:05) Featuring three features on the making of the film: Birthing Mamma Mia!, The Filmmaking and The Cast.
  * Deleted Musical Number - "The Name of the Game" - (2:57) The deleted musical scene featuring Amanda Seyfried and Stellan Skarsgard's character.
  * Anatomy of a Musical Number - "Lay All Your Love On Me" - (5:42) The making of "Lay All Your Love On Me" and Dominic Cooper who is not a singer talks about his experience recording the song and shooting the scene near the beach.
  * Becoming a Singer - (10:55) Benny Anderson (of ABBA) talks about wanting to bring the musicians together in making the music for the film.  Anderson and Ulvaeus talk about working with the talent and the talents talk about their experience working with the ABBA stars for the film and footage of the recordings of the music at the studio.  The male talent who are not known for singing talk about being worried in recording the music.
  * A Look Inside Mamma Mia! The Movie - (2:39) The cast talk about Abba's music and a look at the musical and the film adaptation.
  * Sing-Along - While watching "Mamma Mia! The Movie", you can watch it with a sing-along.
  * Deleted Scenes - (8:06) The deleted scenes from the film.
  * Outtakes - (1:33) The outtakes from the film.
  * "Gimme! Gimme! Gimme!" Music Video - (3:49) The music video of "Gimme! Gimme! Gimme" sung by Amanda Seyfried.
  * Bjorn Ulvaeus Cameo - (1:35) ABBA's Bjorn Ulvaeus cameo in the film.
  * Feature Commentary with Director Phyllida Lloyd - Director Phyllida Lloyd talks about working on the film, bringing the musical to film (Lloyd was responsible for directing the stage version), working with the talent, shooting in Greece, experimenting with day and night shooting and creating the dramatical effect of the film and more.

JUDGMENT CALL:

I don't think I have enjoyed a movie musical like "Mamma Mia! The Movie" since "Grease".  I absolutely felt that Amanda Seyfried shined throughout this film.  Seyfried is absolutely radiant in this fim and since the theatrical release of "Mamma Mia! The Movie", I have been quite impressed by her work.  She's an amazing actress with so much depth and she shows what she is capable of in "Mamma Mia!", definitely far from what we have seen of her in "Mean Girls" and "Veronica Mars".

And Meryl Streep, what a brilliant performance.  It's one thing for Streep to be known as a wonderful award winning actress but somehow there was this synergy that went through the cast and but especially for Meryl Streep, she was electrifying and had so much energy, I was impressed.

The cast was absolutely fun to watch and although some of the talent (specifically the male talent) are not known for singing, I suppose the film brought this naturalness to its characters.

But it all comes down to the music of ABBA, especially if you enjoyed their music in the past.  For me, it was nostalgic as I grew up during the '70s and my parents were part of those disco years and part of my younger life was at home with plenty of people taking part in these disco parties.  So, the music of ABBA didn't bother me and in some ways, some songs really got me interested in how the original music sounds compared to the movie musical and songs such as "Gimme! Gimme! Gimme!" surprised me because I thought the music was first created for Madonna's 2005 song "Hung Up".

But there is so many things that came together for this film that I absolutely enjoyed.  The location was absolutely beautiful, the editing that helped enhance the musical numbers were well-done and as mentioned, the talents were just enjoyable to watch.  This was an enjoyable film that didn't require any seriousness or surrealistic plot, this was a straight-forward fun, vibrant film with an enjoyable cast.

As for the Blu-ray, there are people who enjoy musicals and I know the music of ABBA and disco may be a bit much for some people expecting something along a similar path of movie musicals such as "Moulin Rouge", "Chicago" or "Nine" but "Mamma Mia! The Movie" is a film about having fun and being in love, and I suppose once can say that ABBA's music embodies that.  This is a gorgeous movie on Blu-ray and some may feel the film was too oversaturated for their taste but I felt that there was a sense of artistry in terms of cinematography.

Overall, "Mamma Mia! The Movie" is a wonderful musical on Blu-ray and if you are into musicals, especially the music of ABBA and want something more lively and fun, definitely give this Blu-ray release a try!  Recommended!

I love ABBA's music, but when I borrowed this DVD from the local library I had no idea the story was all written around the music of ABBA. Watched it 4 times, something I never do, and I find myself going to sleep and waking up with the lyrics from Mamma Mia on my lips. Another thing, too: I'm not a rabid dancer. Usually I have to force myself to do it, and it probably shows. But there are few ABBA songs I can listen to without wanting to get up and start gesticulating with my arms and swiveling the old hips. (Sometimes I do!) I don't know what it is about their music, but if you don't want to dance when you hear it, forget it, you'll never be a dancer.

I agree that Pierce Brosnan can't carry a tune, but it didn't bother me too much because I didn't expect him to be vocally talented. He was adequate for the role, probably not his best, but he seemed to enjoy himself nonetheless, and I did, too.

Anyway, I'm sold on the movie, so I'll look for the best deal I can get on my purchase of it. I'll keep it together with my copy of West Side Story. These are the only two stage musicals that were made into movies that captured my enthusiasm. I was really surprised at Meryl Streep's performance. I didn't know she had it in her, having only seen her in heavy dramatic roles.

If the critics didn't like this movie, they should get their TS cards punched, as we used to say in the Army. I can't imagine how anyone could not enjoy the movie, and if people enjoy it, the critics be damned. I didn't find it of inferior quality in any way.

Bottom line, if you haven't seen it, what are you waiting for?

Two facts MOST theater-lovers know early on:

1) Mama Mia on Broadway is the BEST time ever!
2) Movie adaptations of live theater are never as good.

That being said, I have a fresh idea about the recent movie version of ABBA's Mama Mia- FORGET ABOUT THE BROADWAY SHOW! Comparing the stage "Spectacle" and the movie is like comparing a big chocolate cake U can eat, to a picture of a chocolate cake you cannot. The picture of the cake will still make you smile, even if U cannot sink your teeth into it.

I thoroughly enjoyed the movie version of Mama Mia. Essentially a story about a young woman getting married, it becomes a delicious twist of family secrets and revelations. After she reads secret information kept by her mother, Donna, Sophie devises a plan she does not share with her mom. She invites 3 strangers to her wedding, These men are all from her mom's past, a past Donna wants to keep distant. Sophie does share this plan with her 2 best friends and her fiance, BUT only after she sends the invitations. This sets in motion a madcap string of events with short and long-term effects. The audience can now sink their teeth into some fun escapades, as Sophie attempts to keep Donna in the dark as long as possible.

The cast of this movie is a dream. Taking some of Hollywood's Elite adds to the universal appeal to basically a niche(musical)movie. Even those people who are not fans of musicals can enjoy this movie for its star quality.

Meryl Streep, in the lead role of Donna Sheridan, is fantastic. She shows the struggle of a single mom, trying to make ends meet by running a hotel in Greece, very authentically. The range of emotion the part of "Donna" requires, is second nature to Ms. Streep. And, while a complete shock to me, she must have known that her vocal ability was as on par as was needed. She was right. Her version of "The Winner Takes it All" is quite moving. Her transformation from serious, all-work-no-play, hard-nosed Donna to full of Life Donna is fun to watch.

As Sophie Sheridan, Amanda Seyfried, is both dainty and emotional. A relative newcomer(at least compared to the others in the cast) Ms. Seyfried commands the screen whenever she is the main focus. Her scene on the boat with her "fathers" is very moving. She also can carry quite a tune. "Slipping through my Fingers", the duet she shares with Ms. Streep is really fantastic.

The actors playing the 3 potential fathers are not quite up to the task in one way or another. The best of the bunch is Colin Firth, who plays Harry Bright. His voice is quite good, although he has no real solo in the film. He does however have a big secret reveal towards the end of the film that was the one big plot line difference between stage musical and movie. It's a fun scene to witness.

Stellan Skarsgard, as Bill Anderson, is very funny in some scenes, touching in others. His voice is adequate, I guess. "Our Last Summer" is a song he sings with the other "fathers".

Then there is Pierce Brosnan, as Sam Carmichael. As far as acting goes, he is really good. The scenes he shares with Ms. Streep are really well-acted. HOWEVER, his singing is terrible. I mean REALLY BAD. Certain times, I thought a cat was being harmed slightly off camera. Some people were surprised to learn that Mr. Brosnan could sing, then they found out HE CANNOT!!!!!! But he was Bond...James Bond, so cut him some slack.

Two other big names round out the main cast of "Mama Mia". Christine Baranski, as Tanya, a many-times divorced boozer, is one third of Donna and the Dynamos, a girl-group from years ago. Ms Baranski is always a scene-stealer in any movie she is in. During one scene in "Mama Mia", Ms. Baranski tries to avert the advances of a friend of the groom-to-be. She sings "Does Your Mother Know" as a way to both flirt and repel this "YOUNG man". As a veteran of Broadway and the silver screen, Ms. Baranski's acting and vocal talents are very well perfected.

As "Rosie", Julie Walters is the second third of the group. Younger audiences know Ms. Walters as Mrs. Weasley, from the Harry Potter movies. "Rosie" is a semi-famous cookbook author who seems to fall hard for Stellan Skarsgard's "Bill". "Take a chance on me" is her play at a life with Bill. Both are fantastic.

So, Mama Mia, the MOVIE, is a fantastic time. Is it the same as seeing it on Broadway? Certainly not. But for reaching a far more widespread audience, this movie is perfect!

I didn't read the reviews before I ordered the dvd - those critical of Pierce Brosnan's singing might have discouraged me and I would have missed the most delightful of shows. Maybe if you just watched it once you would not have picked up on the brilliant direction of this film. I've seen it probably twelve times in the month I've had it and am still catching the little subtleties that are seemingly everywhere (lady director) and have to admit I like Pierce's singing - but then I liked Eastwood and Marvin's singing in Paint Your Wagon. This is wonderfully cast, and the performances are unforgettable, but be warned the music keeps playing on that jukebox in your mind.

You all know the cast is All-Star. The fact that they all sing their own parts with no `Ghost Singers' makes this romp based on Abba songs all the better. And by the way, Meryl Streep, Julie Walters, and Christine Baranski can sing, and I mean very very well.

The music, the scenery, the scenarios...all very excellent. And people, every actor/actress here can SING. While some think the `Dancing Queen' sequence is great, I think the Dancing Guys In Flippers (only 30 seconds long) is hilarious.

The choreography is superb. The music is great, and the whole thing is just fun.

The plot? Simple. A young girl invites three men (Firth, Brosnan, and Skarsgard) who are totally different, to her wedding. One of them, she believes, is her father. Her mother (Streep) had `encounters' with each. And each man, in return, believes himself to be the daughter he never knew of. Because of this, each man is transformed. Simple, and enough of the plot.

The movie is about the incredible music and dance sequences. Enjoy this film for that simple fact. I know I did.

And by the way, the movie is freaking funny.

But this was one good thing I discovered in that long plane ride.  It was surprisingly entertaining and made me want to dance!  I know the plot is very weak and very unrealistic - one star off for that - (come on, who would go to an old lover's daughter wedding when you have not spoken for 20 years??), but I had so much fun.  I now own the soundtrack and love blasting it.  And every couple months or so, I catch it on HBO since it always puts me in a great mood.  Pierce Brosan is a bit hard to listen to, but Meryl Streep makes it up for him!!
I highly recommend this movie to anyone who just wants to have a good time!

I'm generally not a fan of "jukebox musicals" - musicals that are based around a group of pre-existing songs, with a loosely strung-together plot to connect the dots between the songs on the soundtrack. I went into Mamma Mia not realizing that it was a jukebox musical for ABBA songs, and I left disappointed.

Not that there's anything wrong with the songs on here - they're catchy and upbeat, if you like that sort of thing - that is, if you like ABBA. If you're not here for the ABBA songs, though, the musical comes off as flimsy and anemic - with several plot points seemingly out of place, largely in order to lead into another ABBA song. Indeed, without the basic understanding that "Mamma Mia" is a jukebox musical, a lot of songs feel strangely out of place - "Honey, Honey", in particular, seems oddly sensual for a young woman to be fantasizing about her mother's lovers. The setting and timeline, too, are badly muddled - the musical takes place in Greece, but "Mamma Mia!" carries Italian overtones, and "Our Last Summer" wistfully places them in France when, to judge from all other plot points, they weren't. Mama mia, but this is very confusing to a viewer not in the know.

If you really like ABBA songs, you may enjoy this musical, but I found the soundtrack to be the strongest feature of this movie. The actual plot itself is very flimsy, and often feels like an excuse to rush to the next song. The acting and singing is superb, and the movie is well-cast, but it's hard to hang a meaningful, compelling plot on a handful of catchy dance songs.

~ Ana Mardoll

Let's face it. If Meryl Streep was cast in a Fruit of the Loom commercial, she would still be the standout piece of produce, lending conviction to a one-dimensional part others would easily dismiss as too superficial. That's the way to view this ebullient, featherweight 2008 confection based on the long-running jukebox musical from the prolific songbook of 1970's super-pop group ABBA, all of which were written by bandmates Benny Andersson and Bjrn Ulvaeus. Even though there is barely a part there, Streep throws herself into Donna like it was Sophie Zawistowski,Karen Blixen, or Miranda Priestly. She also gets to perform the lioness' share of the over two dozen songs that drive the flimsy, derivative storyline over its 108-minute running time. If you've ever seen an underrated 1968 Gina Lollobrigida farce called Buona Sera Mrs Campbell, you'll recognize the plot straight away since it pilfers the same basic idea. This time, we are focused on the upcoming nuptials for Sophie, the beautiful twenty-year-old daughter of Donna, a resourceful hippie-chick who runs a dilapidated inn on a stunning Greek island. To make the chronology work, the story, one can assume, is set sometime in the late 1990's as Donna apparently led a hedonistic lifestyle in the late 1970's when she became pregnant while fronting a girl-group called Donna and the Dynamos. This becomes pertinent because Sophie's paternity is a big question mark and is about to be answered because Sophie clandestinely invites the three men who could possibly be her father to her wedding - staid British banker Harry, adventurous Swedish travel writer Bill, and divorced architect Sam. The inevitable complications ensue when all three show up on the idyllic island, each coming to the conclusion that he is indeed Sophie's father. Meanwhile, Donna invites the Dynamos - now best-selling cookbook author Rosie and multiple-married, cosmetically altered Tanya. Add Sophie's intended, a hunky beach boy named Sky and his equally tanned and toned pals, as well as her two giggly bridesmaids and a rhythmic chorus of Greek villagers - and you indeed have a musical revue for anyone in the mood for one. At the same time, that's the caveat because you have to love ABBA's music to be enthralled by a movie riddled with flaws. The pacing often feels off, especially when characters belabor their individual dilemmas ad nauseam. Some of the choreography in the production numbers feels amateurish, and the cinematography frequently looks washed out (Streep looks particularly pasty and red-eyed in certain scenes). These lapses probably have to do with the arguable decision to have the Broadway crew of producer Judy Craymer, writer Catherine Johnson, and director Phyllida Lloyd translate all this to the screen, none of whom have any significant filmmaking experience. Perhaps a Rob Marshall could have lent a more polished sheen to the proceedings, but then again, there is a certain camp value that makes you wonder whether the whole venture is meant to be a parody of a good musical. Note the energetic "Dancing Queen" number which feels like a Bollywood production number with all the village women parading down to the dock in exaggerated unison. In the end, I guess it doesn't matter since a game cast has been recruited to make it all work at the intended level of fun. Streep shines without peer and sings with supple conviction on lighthearted ditties like the title tune and "Money, Money, Money", as well as the more emotive ballads like "Slipping Through My Fingers" and "The Winner Takes It All". She can't help Pierce Brosnan who duets with her sounding like a wounded cow on "S.O.S." (The audience erupted in laughter whenever he sang). However, he regains some of his self-respect when he plays Sam straight-up. The other two actors - Stellan Skarsgrd as Bill and the omnipresent Colin Firth as Harry - are also likeable though hardly challenged in their roles. Julie Walters as Rosie and Christine Baranski as Tanya perform petty larceny in stealing their scenes, especially in their specialty numbers. As the hopeful Sophie, bright-eyed Amanda Seyfried is sweet without being cloying and has a bell-like voice which she shows off well on the bookend anthem, "I Have a Dream". The climactic wedding party scene is like watching news footage of Sydney's Mardi Gras festivities, while the end credits flash on a karaoke reprise of "Dancing Queen" complete in Vegas drag-queen regalia followed by a funny encore of "Waterloo" (my personal favorite in the ABBA songbook). Go at your own risk...you may love it.

I'm not going to nit-pick like a critic and just express my own opinion of this movie - I loved it! I grew up on ABBA's music as my parents were fans and remember singing and dancing to "Dancing Queen" when I was seven (such memories!). I have loved ABBA ever since, and it was only recently that I actually got to watch the movie (sadly, on DVD, as I missed it during its theater run). Though the actors do not remotely resemble (nor sing like) the singers of ABBA, they more than make up for it with genuine chemistry and camaraderie. A viewer can tell these actors had great fun during the production of this musical/movie and their fun is incredibly infectious! I sang out loud and even danced to the old, familiar, classic songs, and had so much fun! The main cast is made up of famous actors - the incomparable Meryl Streep (who really showcases her beautiful singing voice here), the svelte Christine Baranski, and Julie Walters (I remember her most from her role as Mrs Weasley in the Harry Potter movie franchise), Pierce Brosnan (yes, he does not exactly have a great singing voice, but who cares???), Colin Firth (whose performance as Mr. Darcy in Pride and Prejudice left an indelible impression on me), Stellan Skarsgaard, and the two young and talented actors, Amanda Seyfried as Sophie, and Dominic Cooper as her fiance, Sky (the pair are a real-life couple and reportedly began dating on the set of the movie).

The story begins with 20-year-old Sophie Sheridan who discovers that any one of three men (Brosnan, Firth, or Skarsgaard) could be her father. Wishing to have her father (Sophie was raised by her mother,Donna played by Meryl Streep) walk her down the aisle at her wedding to Sky (Dominic Cooper), Sophie invites all three men to her wedding. The clueless Donna invites her two former backup singers to the wedding (Baranski and Walters), and when she sees the three men from her past, all hell breaks loose, and so does the music! The plot is quite thin, and the characters are not explored in-depth here - but the focal point of the movie is the music. The plot revolves around the music, and the lively dance numbers showcase great choreography. The fashion is reminiscent of ABBA's heyday and the costumes are in a riot of colors - all in all, pure rip-roaring fun!

This is a fun movie that brings back nostalgic memories. I will be adding this to my DVD collection. Someday, I hope to watch the Broadway musical.

I avoided seeing this film for a long time because, in the late 70's, I was over-saturated with ABBA. Being somewhat of a film aficianado, I've come to believe that Meryl Streep is among the finest of actresses...ever. I had to check out her musical romp, and I wasn't disappointed. Everyone knows she has a great voice (Postcards from the Edge, Ironweed) and I'm surprised she hasn't been used in other musical endeavors. Regardless, I enjoyed "Mamma Mia!" a lot; a sweet love story centering around middle'aged types. How refreshing. I was entertained a lot, and if you weren't, maybe you should lighten up a bit. I enjoyed the entire cast of old pros, and also the lovely Amanda Seyfried as the catalyst of all the silliness that ensues. It's so silly, but I applaud the film for its unrelenting energy. Kick back, have popcorn and beverages of choice, and enjoy this attempt to bring back the exhuberant musical style that hasn't been successful since "Grease" (1978) or "Hair" (1979). Meryl Streep really shines, once again.

This poorly made, highly obnoxious and often annoying musical is so over-the-top with deliciously tacky charm that it almost demands you enjoy it.  The scary thing is that, for the most part, I did.  I remember turning to my wife after the film had ended and muttering the words "that was awkward" and maybe that is part of the charm.  No one seems entirely comfortable with their role in this film, and that layer of discomfort kind of adds a tinge of adorableness to the film and its vast array of characters.

That doesn't mean that this is a good movie, just a fun one.

The story is of young Sophie who lives on this crazy island with her single mother who runs a hotel on the verge of a breakdown.  When Sophie decides to get married she wants to have her father walk her down the isle (what young girl doesn't).  There is just one problem; she doesn't know who he is.  After reading her mother's diary she discovers that there are three possibilities; Sam, Bill or Harry.  She decides to invite all of them to her wedding in order to discover who her father really is, but when they arrive she realizes that finding him is going to be harder than she thought.

The film is ridiculous and just a hodgepodge of overzealous musical numbers that are so focused on zany choreography that they forget the most important aspect of a musical number is the singing.

Despite this, I cannot say I was not entertained.

The best acting award goes to Streep (is that really a surprise).  She is so over-the-top yet thoroughly committed so that even when she's all over the place it is in a good way.  She is clearly having a blast filming this and it shows all over her face.  Surprisingly, young Amanda Seyfried actually holds her own and delivers a nicely tuned performance.  It doesn't hurt that out of the entire cast they are the only two who can sing (Streep has a few pitch problems but she actually soars on her final number).  Christine Baranski is funny, as is Walters.  Colin Firth is, well, Colin Firth (you gotta love this guy) and Stellan Skarsgard (who I've been a fan of for some time) delivers one of the more sympathetic `fatherly' performances.

Pierce Brosnan is a revelation here, and not in a good way.  His voice is GOD-AWFUL (he sounds like a dying walrus, or a drowning man with Down syndrome; take your pick).  I'm really surprised they allowed him to sing his own songs (I'm really surprised they didn't recast the whole film to be honest beings that the two female leads are the only ones who somewhat make it through this film with dignity).

His Razzie was certainly owed him.

Don't expect a good film (I hope you aren't), but do expect to have a good time.  I can see why this is so loved, for it is lovable.  It is very poorly made (even the dancing numbers seem choppy and sloppy), but Streep does wonders for the film to be honest.  Her ability to just throw caution to the wind and embrace the campy mess that she has been dealt simply draws in the audience and lets them know that it's okay to turn off your brain and have a good time.

Even Meryl Streep knows that this movie is horrible.
This movie will put you into a happy mood. The actors were made for the parts, Iv'e watched it so many times. I had to buy it.

First, I have a fond spot in my heart for Abba and their music. What a great script, a great score, fun actors all around... but Meryl Streep ruins this film for me.  Her performance is wayyyy over the top.  She's trying to play 15 years younger and it just doesn't work.  Absolutely horrible performance.  She should have won the Razzy for worst performance of the year!  The ABC show Modern Family had a wonderful joke about her performance in a recent episode, basically, the gay character loved her and the straight one didn't. I feel that this joke epitomizes my feeling about her in this role.  If you love all musicals, then you'll probably like this one.  If you actually care about acting and craft you'll probably agree with me that Streep's performance is unwatchable.

5 Stars to script, songs, supporting cast, location.

When I don't like a movie or book very much, and many others do, I try to think of why.  In this case I concluded that this movie was made for middle aged women who are trying to remember their youth, who remember it as more glorious than it was.  Amd whenever any such work is so narrowly aimed, it is bound to be sub-standard.

I realize that this was a successful play with music by a popular source.  Maybe the play was okay--but not for me.  The plot of the movie, however, is lame, lame, lame--one for all the prospective fathers of the bride.  The casting was grossly inappropriate with few exceptions.  I just saw the movie and can't remember a single song.  The scenery was nice enough, but most varied, according to IMDB.  It was shot at a couple of places in Greece--and partly in a London studio--and on California beaches, probably because there sere no nice beaches on that Greek isle.  So the producers couldn't even be honest or coherent with the background.  If you want to visit that Greek island after this, you'll need to include the Pacific Ocean, etc.

Now, the movie felt interminable.  It was very poorly edited, with meaningless scenes and dialogue.  People were jumping all over the place, or falling off roofs, or dangling from this or that--all in an attempt, perhaps, to lend life to something that was DOA for me.  "Hair" it is not.  As an update for the hippie participants, it's a wash.  I liked "Hair" but not "Mamma Mia," which, by the way, is Italian, not Greek.

I bought the Mamma Mia tape explicitly for my twin grandchildren who love the music and at six years old know all the words to all songs.  I love the music and scenery also and think it is better than the stage play although Pierce Brosnan cannot sing.
I really enjoyed this movie!  The cast was amazing and the locations were spectacular!!  Lots of great bonus features too!!

The movie itself is rather mediocre.  The singing in this movie is borderline atrocious with tinny voices and actors who have no ability to carry a tune.  All the best ABBA songs were performed at the first half of the movie leaving you singing along to some of the worst pop music ever sang at the latter half.  ABBA created a lot of awful music, just remember that.  Only at the very end when Meryl Streep sings atop a seaside cliff that the movie gets redeemed.  That scene was gorgeous and looked imamculate in Bluray and for top-end TVs.

The camera work and the scenes are beautiful.  I have my picture setting to two notches above normal but not 'vivid'.
Loved the movie, loved the musical and couldn't wait to receive the DVD so I could watch again at home.  Thanks for the fast delivery.

It does not matter what this story is of-ABBA music says it all.

And nice semi-naked bodies of any gender performers either add to a visual pleasure.
great
This purchase was guaranteed to be a pleaser because I saw the movie and fell in love with it.  So happy to get it at a less expensive price than from a video store.
I bought it for my daughter and she just loves it!! She sees it over and over again.

My girlfriend and I watched this one evening and had a blast laughing.  The changes in the original ABBA songs worked well, and the upbeat attitude was refreshing.  Yes, Brosnan needed an SOS with the singing, and Streep's scene singing The Winner Takes it All was overexposed and flat.  The supporting cast more than made up for those shortcomings and other songs were wonderfully uplifting.  We found ourselves humming the tunes over and over.  If you liked ABBA and disco but don't want to admit it, watch this movie.

I love this movie!! it is soooooo cute and it makes you feel so good. it's funny, the music is phenomenal, and everything just works perfectly!

the scenery is gorgeous, and Meryl Streep makes us fall in love with her all over again!

I love Love ABBA! and i'm glad that their timeless music is being represented this way. If you're gay, you are going to LOVE this movie, so watch it now, It's a definate MUST-SEE!

I HIGHLY RECCOMEND THIS!

The music and scenes from Greece were great!!!!
Meryl Streep was perfect as the Mother!!! And, The "Flipper Dance" on the dock is funny as hell!!!! LOL

This was a movie I really loved. I watched it at least 7 times and it always gives me a smile on my face. Meryl Streep and Christine Baranski and Julie Walters made the show. They were great together. Everytime I want to just sit and have a smile on my face, I just put on Mama Mia. It was shipped quickly, packaged very good and in great condition,.
Thank you and God Bless.....

This movie is a awesome movie. It's uplifting and I can relate to most of the stuff on this movie. Crazy, corny, tear jerker, funny, exciting. A sweet romance. Fun musical.

My mother in law LOVES this movie so I was coerced into watching it last night.  It was TERRIBLE!  First I don't like watching grown women running around and squealing like 12 year olds at a pajama party.  I mean how old are these people?  The whole cast acted like 12 year olds.  High School Musical was more mature!  But the defining moment came when Remington Steele (Brosnan) and Mr. Darcy (Colin Firth) became complete and total buffoons.  I grew up with Remington Steele and Brosnan will always be Remington Steele to me, comical yet sophisicated and elegant.  Colin Firth in A&E's production of Pride & Prejudice was brilliant as Mr. Darcy.  I expected more mature and serious roles of Brosnan and Firth.  I mean did they intentionally want to play buffoons because they certainly did a good job at it.  I suffered in silence until Brosnan started singing 'I Do, I Do, etc.' and then I lost it.  How ridiculous!  Yeah right.  He's loved her for 21 years.  Sure. Until then I just found the movie immature and childish; that performance made it a complete and total joke.  The only saving aspect of this movie was the music, and that was pretty much ruined by the terrible performance of Brosnan.  The other singers were tolerable but very lacking compared to the broadway musical and ABBA itself.  This wasn't a 'feel good' movie; it was an embarassment and painful to watch.

Probably the best uplifting entertaining movie I've seen in a long, long time.
Love the entire cast and the great music.  We need more movies like Mamma Mia!!!!!!!!!!
I've still not gone through all the features, but have used the free digital download to put the movie in my Iphone.  Love it!

In order to enjoy this movie, you should be a fan or at least like ABBA's songs because the whole Mamma Mia's idea is just an excuse for letting the grateful viewers/listeners experience their favorite songs in a relaxing and feeling good setting on a colorful sunny idyllic Greek isle surrounded by the bluest sea you can imagine. I consider myself a loyal ABBA's fan. I still remember how I heard their songs for the first time almost thirty years ago, how happy I was to be able to own their albums on LPs, how much I enjoyed ABBA: The Movie (1977) which came to Moscow in the beginning of the 1980s and was basically the record of their concerts in Sydney, Melbourne, Perth and Adelaide. I also saw the famous musical Mamma Mia on which the last year movie is based on and I liked it a lot. It would not hurt if you can take with humor outrageous psychedelic outfits of the 1970s and the tight boots with the platforms so huge that it makes your feet hurt just to look at them. If that sounds like your idea of fun, fun you'll have. I sure did, at least for the first hour or to be precise until the very moment, Pierce Brosnan had ruined my favorite ABBA's song S.O.S by attempting to sing it. I guess it is sometimes easier to save the world from all sorts of evil than just to sing a song. While that torture lasted, I kept repeating instead of S.O.S, S.O.E which means Save Our Ears. I later found out that when asked during an interview why he took the role, Brosnan replied that when he heard from his agent, "Mamma Mia, Meryl Streep", he took it without asking whom he'd play. Well, acting next to Streep is a great reason, and I believe Brosnan had a lot of fun sharing the screen with her. I also believe that there is nothing impossible for Meryl. She can play anything and anybody. Just to think what she has done in all the movies she has graced with her presence. She did very convincing accents, she learned how to play a violin, she dances, she has been a villain and a saint, and everybody in between and she's been always the reason to watch any movie. While watching Mamma Mia, I got the crazy idea. What if Meryl played all six older characters, Donna, her two girlfriends and three men from her past? I know it sounds weird but if Eddie Murphy could do it, I am sure Meryl Streep could act and sing for six characters and she would be simply fabulous. Between Streep and young talented Amanda Seyfried, two of them made a nice singing/acting team. But even with Meryl playing and singing only one part, the film is still entertaining and fun mostly due to the fact that everyone involved had a good time on the charming little island, the serious actors were not afraid to make fools out of themselves for all of us to enjoy, and in the end everyone was happy and got what they wanted even if it was not exactly what they wanted in the beginning of the movie.

The Blu Ray version is one of the best transfers I've seen on this platform.  The colors are saturated and sparkling.  The film version of the hit musical offers stunning production values and memorable ABBA tunes with updated arrangements.  What's not to like?  While traditional Hollywood musicals often featured singers of less than stellar talents (e.g. Fred Astaire) these stars were usually paired with someone who was an A-list singer.  A frothy, fun musical doesn't require extraordinary acting skill, so having Meryl Streep in the lead role is a bit odd.  If the producers felt the picture needed someone of that stature, it would have made more sense to go with someone who was also an accomplished singer, such as Glenn Close.  The time-honored alternative is to dub the singing parts with a ghost singer, which is what should have been done for Mr. Brosnan's part.  The off-key, lackluster singing really drags down this otherwise beautiful film as many of the musical sequences are quite long. It reminds me of Ross Hunter's forgotten musical production of "Lost Horizon" which as doomed by its cast of casual singers. You might want to rent this film before you buy to determine if you'd really want to view it many times.

Is Meryl Streep perfect in Mamma Mia?  Just about, though everything else carries with it the least little hint of could have been better.  When they announced the movie and said that Olivia Newton John might be playing Donna, we all cheered, and then when it seemed like Michelle Pfeiffer was getting the nod, we were even happier.  Frankly, Meryl Streep gets everything nowadays, can't they give it to someone whose career could use the boost?  But she can sing and of course she can act up a storm.  Donna never seems to think twice about what she is going to the Greek coastline with her enormous tourist hotel and employing all the Greek islanders as her gofers.  How does she pay any of them I wonder, if the business is as bad as she claims?

How did Amanda Seyfried get to meet those two bridesmaids who seem to have wandered in from a movie like BLOW-UP--tall, leggy, older supermodels indistinguishable from each other, not a single personality between them.  They just make Sophie look like a midget, can she really be that short?  I used to like Seyfried, but her goofy swoons every time her mother sings are too forced.  I like exuberance, but hers is cooked up like heroin sizzling in a spoon.  And yet, she's not awful, and in fact she does a pretty good job convincing us that she really wants to find out who her father is.  This must speak to a lot of people who don't know their fathers, I guess, but for the rest of us, it is not motivation enough--it is the opposite of motivation--countermotivation perhaps.  Amanda Seyfried and Dominic what's his name have chemistry during their big number Lay All Your Love on Me, possibly ABBA's sexiest tune, but otherwise I'm looking at him wondering what the big deal is.  A star of tomorrow, I don't think so.

What a missed opportunity for Meryl Streep to have introduced Abba's "JUST LIKE THAT" to the world.  ABBA fans know that "MAMMA MIA" the stage musical actually had a "Just Like That" scene which was trimmed during out of town tryouts.  Here she does a fine job with "The Winner Takes It All," but no one can actually perform that one better than the original by Agnetha Faltskog... maybe Meryl Streep is too levelheaded a person really to put that song over.  Is she ever really down, or does she find a little bit of hope even in her darkest hour?  With Agnetha we knew that everything in the universe was and is and remains doomed, for the gods, cold as ice, throw a dice and decide our fate.

Dear Amazion,
The service outstanding,I am planing order again in the further.
The book was in excellent condition. Delivery was fast.
Thank you
Douglas Coad

This is a refreshing musical romance.  A mother is preparing for her daughter's wedding while the daughter has discovered three possible men who could be her father.  All three come to the island and find they are all drawn to the daughter.  This is a must have family film.  Enjoy!
No surprises... got what I asked for, when I asked for it, at a fair price.  This is a fun movie with just a few brief pg-13 scenes... good music and beautiful scenery.

I was hesitant about watching this movie because of the bad reviews. I am so glad I watched this movie anyway. What a touching funny movie. I adore "Momma Mia."
Meryl Streep was a goddess. All the actors and actresses were right on. My aunt and I are still singing some of the songs from the movie. You have to watch this movie at least 3 times to get the full affect. The scenery was to die for.
Pierce Brosnan was gorgeous. Some of my favorite parts were when when Donna was painting her daughter's toes before the wedding. Plus, the song "When all is said and Done" was purely for the teary eyed person to relish. This was a funny, sweet, tear jerker movie.
 A must see for anyone loving movies with heart.
I know I will be watching it again and again.
Now, if I could sing these songs without breaking the windows....
 we would really be talking!!
Plus, the ending where they wore those gaudy costumes ,was hysterical!
It looked like everyone in the movie was enjoying themselves. They looked so happy and carefree. That's a good kind of movie to be in. A movie where everyone looked so happy just to be there. It showed in their faces and their performances.

((My initial review is below...))  ..But I had to come back & re-review, because, after all, it's a fantasy.  Certainly I'd watch it over Sex and the City the movie.  My mom wanted Mama Mia for Christmas & I watched it again with her~ Not terrible.  Fun, little silly movie.  Yeah.  I'm goin' with that.
Also published a revised p.o.v. under comments.

Old, dramatic review:  (yoish)
...Unless you're in an altered state, I just --You'd have to hog-tie me to make me see this movie again.
To go into details is too negative, so I'll just say... ..  Oh my goodness Singing (except for Amanda, who is Wonderful): Pass...
Choreography?  Please~ No More!!!!  No!  Pass! Passss!!!!
{ )  Save yourself the Pain and the 2 hours of your life you'll NEVER get back!  Pass!!!!

I had no desire to see this movie and caught it changing channels.  It was the opening scene and my remote was like a car slamming on the brakes.  To heck with all critics, this movie will make you smile.  It is an interlude of contagious fun and in times like these we desperately need this!  I thought all the actors were great.  It wasn't the quailty of their singing that mattered (which was great) but the abandon with which they totally jumped into the characters.  Brosnan was adorable.  You WILL smile.

If you like musicals you will love this one - I could not believe that all of the actors could sing.  I am glad that they actually had the actors sing the songs - it was great and i watch this one over and over.  I love the music so I went out and purchased the sound track.

The review title says it all.  Meryl Streep is a great actress but in this role looked totally out of her element.  She appeared wooden throughout.  Pierce Brosnan was a joke as a singer.  Perhaps with some genuine musical theater stars in the role, it may have worked.  Even so, I got so tired of its teeny-bopper mentality, even from the adults, that I soon came to understand why the late-night comedians made such fun of this film.  Is it a feel-good film?  Yes (my 81-year-old mother-in-law liked it), but much of the "feel-good" comes from laughing AT it.  The blu-ray transfer was excellent, which befits the great ocean-front scenery, the movie's greatest asset.  It sure wasn't the musical performances from Streep and Brosnan.

My wife made me go to see this, because all the PMT ridden harpies in her office were raving about the film. I tried to refuse but she overpowered me with her mind-games.

I wanted to go to the cinema, sit in the dark and sulk.

But they wouldn't let me.

Maybe it was the warmth of the Greek sun mixed with the melodies of ABBA but after only a few minutes I couldn't help but feel happier. Damn them.

By the middle of the film I was laughing as loudly as everyone else, and finally I jumped up onto my feet during the finale to spin my beloved up the aisle.

As I left the cinema, feeling giddy and warm (my wife and I talked about nonsense all the way home on the train - just laughing and joking over silly things) - I realised that the film had transformed the both of us for the night. We did not talk about the film, but the joy and freedom and sense of fun it gave us remained.

The next day I read many of the critical reviews, nearly all panned the film, and although I can objectivly see that the film was not the most technically accomplished, I have two reasons why I think my wife and I loved the experience so much.

1. I cannot remember seeing a film featuring people my own age actually having fun. Not 'acting' like they are having fun but actually have a romp. Hollywood take note - we live in an ageing population and people of my age like seeing the vitality that can be afforded to us rather than being reminded that we are just too old to face transforming robots. (ps - 41 is not old)

2. The music of ABBA has tremendous power, even after all these years. I have always enjoyed their melodies, the complex arrangements give their sound a surprising depth. Integrated into the film, flimsy as the plot is, just produces a renewed vigour to it - like meeting an old friend that you have not seen for years.

Forget the critics, like aimless children in a playground they follow whatever the zeitgeist dictates, trying to convince us of what is note worthy and important. They offer analytical pieces that nail all of the technical faults of this film but have managed to miss all of it's emotional triumphs. Just see this film - you may hate it - but there are too many of us saying that this film 'just' made us feel happy. In times like these that is a valuable ability and gift not to be missed.

A bubbly and fun musical with lighthearted songs and great cast.  Who would have thought Meryl Streep and Pierce Brosnan could carry a tune and put themselves so totally into a lighthearted musical?  It works!

If you want something happy and full of energy and jumping dance music it is a good movie to watch.

The music is from the Swedish Rock Group, "Abba"  - and although "campy" it is fresh and vibrant again in this romantic scenario.

Sophie, a young girl is about to be married.  (Sophie is played by Amanda Seyfried.)  She lives on a beautiful Greek island with her mother, Donna (Streep).  Together they work hard to keep up a run-down resort.  They are preparing for Sophie's wedding and Sophie feels the need to know who her real father is, and wants him with her during this special time.  She had read her mother's diary and there were three possibilities on who her father is.  She invites each to attend her wedding without her mother's knowledge.

Sam (Pierce Brosnan), Harry (Colin Firth), and Bill (Stellan Skarsgard) all arrive on the same boat.

Donna finds out they are at her resort and is absolutely shocked to meet her old lovers again after 20 years have patched.  Her two best friends, Tanya (Christine Baranaki) and Rosie (Julia Walters), for their advice and help on how to get through the next few days.  Sophie finds time to be with the three men and looks for clues on who her real dad is.  Again, the unexpected surprise is Streep, Brosman and even Christine Baranski - singing and having fun with this romantic romp.  No matter how schmaltzy Abba can be it is just a "sparkly"  time for all.

First, this is a review of the movie, not the DVD as I saw Mamma Mia! in the theater.

I only went to see the beautiful Greek scenery, having no interest in seeing a musical, nor in Abba songs, nor in Mamma Mia! the musical from stage.  I expected to be a bit bored, and boy was I happily mistaken!

This movie is a whole lot of fun.  The actors are great.  There is madcap sort of storyline about a woman who raises her daughter alone on a Greek island and the men who may be that girl's father.  It's great fun, over the top, madcap, even silly humor.  The songs fit right in and just add to the fun spirit of the movie.  What a great summer movie this is.

I don't recall every plot twist and turn, but do recall feeling very happy and entertained.  It's a very upbeat movie.

And of course, the scenery is beautiful.

I must admit, I had seen all the bad reviews, and had drawn back from watching this movie. I now know that THAT was a mistake! It may be a guilty pleasure, but I found this charming, with a wonderful sense of the use of the songs of ABBA that I've loved for years. Yes, it is a little over the top -- but when was the last time you watched "An American in Paris?" I re-watched it lately, and talk about over the top! But IT WORKS and is considered a classic. That's because the MUSIC works. The same could be said for "Mama Mia". Maybe not on the same level -- ABBA is not on par with Gershwin, after all -- but they never pretended to be, either.

I knew Meryl Streep could sing (she does it very well in "A Prairie Home Companion" and "Postcards from the Edge"), but Colin Firth surprised me pleasantly. And could anything be funnier (or campier) than Christine Baranski's "Does Your Mother Know?" And I certainly cannot remember a more unique (or funnier) dance sequence than is in "Lay All Your Love On Me!"

I'm well over 50, so I remember those clothes, those awful platform shoes, and how the music critics savaged ABBA as being "cotton candy" music. So ignore the critics. This movie will bring back some happy memories (if you are as old as I am!), and make some new ones!

I really dredded having to watch "Mamma Mia." I heard alot of bad reviews,even my Sister hated the film,but it did make alot of money,so I knew someone liked it.
After seeing the movie I didn't like it either,I LOVED IT.
First of all,Meryl Streep can do ANYTHING.If she's in a movie,you know it has to be great. She can sing and dance like there's no tommow.
Its wonderfull seeing actors over 50 singing and dancing,and having fun for once in a movie. Most films have actors over 50 in the background,this one has them featured.
 Amanda Seyfried  has the best singing voice,and she's wonderfull in the film,but Pierce Brosnan takes alittle getting use to,but he gives it his best.
"Mamma Mia"is a Musical Classic  I look forward to watching again.

Pierce Brosnan really does suck in this and I think was completely miscast.  But it is fun and silly and a harmless way to spend time if you don't mind ABBA music being sung badly.  The stage musical was better.

"Mamma Mia" boasts an all-star cast and fantastic music by ABBA, but it doesn't rank as one of my favorite movie musicals of all time. The story revolves around Sophie (Amanda Seyfried), a 20-year-old girl about to tie the knot on the beautiful island she resides on with her mother, Donna (Meryl Streep). Sophie has no idea who who father is (neither does Donna, for that matter), so she invites the three possible candidates (Pierce Brosnan, Colin Firth, and Stellan Skarsgard) to her wedding in hopes of reuniting with her true paterfamilias. Needless to say, Donna isn't exactly thrilled when three of her former lovers show up unexpectedly on the eve of her daughter's wedding, and of course hilarious hijinks ensue, followed by a totally unrealistic yet ridiculously happy ending.

The best part of this film is watching some of my favorite Hollywood actors sing and dance like crazy.
