I LOVE THIS MOVIE!  I am very impressed with Amazon.com's shipping!  I preordered this movie and got it the day before it even came out in stores.  Very happy customer.

I have to admit I was a skeptic.  I was not a huge fan of ABBA growing up but after the broadway show came out, which I did not see, I started to think maybe I will give it a shot and see what it is about.  I like musicals.
I sat down on a cold January 4th and watched it.  I love it!
I think my favorite part of the movie is Dancing Queen.  I loved how the older woman carrying sticks on her back just threw them down and joined in the fun.
By the way, the other reason I wanted to watch it is because it has Colin Firth in it.  Not bad on the vocals.
As for Pierce, back off people I have heard a lot worse.  I think it catches you off guard more than anything.  I have watched it twice now and even the second time, I really don't think he sounds that bad.
It says a lot throwing yourself into a role that is completely different from what you normally do.  He took a chance and had some fun.
I like this movie.  Guess I need to check out the Broadway production sometime.

I absolutely LOVED this movie -- I had never seen the musical...actually, I'm not a big fan of musicals as a rule (except for film version of "Grease")...so I was pleasantly surprised to find myself smiling and dancing in my seat throughout the entire film. Talk about a feel-good movie! I wanted to be a member of the cast dancing alongside Meryl -- oh  and Meryl, what a VOICE! Is there anything this woman can't do?! I have long admired her as an exceptional actress, but her choice to do this film raises my admiration even more, because it shows she knows how to have fun! And that's how I would sum up this movie: FUN! I wouldn't necessarily recommend this film to someone who doesn't like ABBA, but even if you only like a few of their songs you might be surprised to find yourself bopping along to ALL of the music!
My Mom loved the movie and all the bonus features. No issues with this purchase.

I loved the movie and pre-ordered the DVD that came on time, as Amazon has always been perfect on. The "making of" if very good, although I would have loved to know even more about the actors and how they prepared for the role, which is mostly what people care about.
Overall, really a great movie and great "making of".

This movie is one of the best movies ever made. Meryl Streep never does anything bad anyway, but this one just can't be missed. Even gave this as a gift to daughter and family and she watched it 7 times....  We will watch this over and over, just as we do Out of Africa.
I enjoyed the movie and am glad to have the dvd to watch whenever I want to.  I also purchased the cd and play it in my car all the time!
This is a really fun movie and I knew all the lyrics! Why doesn't Hollywood make movies like this more?

I grew up with ABBA through high school and they have always been a guilty pleasure so I was really looking forward to this movie. (I haven't had a chance to see the play.) What a disappointment. The singing was terrible (with the exception of the daughter) and the acting just as bad. I haven't seen a musical this embarrassing since "Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band" (which at least had decent singing but was still so bad it managed to effectively kill the careers of both the Bee Gees and Peter Frampton).

I have always DISLIKED ABBA - however, against my better judgement, I saw the stageshow in London soon after it was presented and liked it very much (all except the mob dance at the end).  I have been looking forward to seeing the film, especially with Meryl Streep on board.  The cast is great BUT what a miserable disaster this movie is.  The mistake is that the director has filmed a STAGESHOW.  The movie is exhausting!  Everyone RUNS and no one seems to walk.  The production numbers blend into one.  The facial expressions are all overdone.  In other words, a stageshow has been filmed.  A total disappointment.  I was also NOT IMPRESSED with the actors - Julie Walters looked terrible, the men were hopeless and had no singing voices and even Meryl Streep was not at her best.  The three women were also disappointing.  A total flop for me .......... but I am sure that I am in the minority here just as I was when ABBA first burst on the scene back in the 70's.  Makes you remember just how good the Beatles really were!

While my two-year old great nephew was derailing a runaway Lionel train around the Christmas tree and had totally wrecked a ranch-style plastic home, my other great nephews and great niece were exhorting me to open the presents they brought me. Knowing I had seen the play on Broadway three times and once in Toronto, it was no surprise that "Momma Mia," the DVD was behind the decorative Christmas paper. "Oh, can we watch it, Uncle Ed?" (If ever a gift could keep on giving right back to the givers)!

Even though Meryl Streep is old enough to be a grandmother (and probably is), the camera never gets too close to her face, as she plays a barely middle-aged mother of a love-struck daughter on the verge of marriage. The daughter discovers that Mom was a bit wilder in her youth having made love to three men at approximately the same time. The plot unfolds when she decides to invite her "fathers" to the wedding without her mother's knowledge. MOMMA MIA!

This is loosely based on a late 60's movie titled "Buona Sera, Mrs. Campbell," where the twist is that Gina Lollabrigitta tells three American World War II veterans that they are the father of her son. Their guilt and money provide for the same. Only here, the setting is an unnamed Greek isle instead of Italy, and mom is barely scraping by running what can be charitably called an inn.

An unabashed ABBA fan, I enjoy each hit over and over again, and could play them all day. I play them when I am in a good mood, and when I need to get in a good mood. The music from this can be found on the CD for the movie (d'uh), or ABBA Gold, which has every one but, "I do."

So, love me or leave me, but please don't deceive me, because I won't deceive you. Meryl Streep reveals her absolute depth in her performance. Her ending with her co-stars is a triumph of harmony on stage or at Waterloo where Napoleon did surrender. Pierce Brosnan's bellowing efforts might make you want to suck on a lemon while someone is running steel fingernails across a blackboard, but the movie is fun even in a rich man's world, or for a super trouper. The supporting cast was superb. I was particularly impressed with Julie Walters who played one of Meryl Streep's adult sidekicks. Christine Baranski was predictably good. I never imagined that Stellan Skaarsgard could kick up a storm the way he did.

My gift included a trailer that allowed the viewer to see the making of the movie, and the songs being replayed in the movie with the words appearing, but without the bouncing ball. It helped me learn a lot of the correct words that men seem to have a harder time identifying them than women do when it comes to song. (Up to age 50, I thought Popeye was strong to the "pinach" cuz I eats me spinach).

Do I recommend this DVD? I ask in all honesty, without a song or dance what are we? So I say thank you for the music, (and the DVD,) for giving it to me. Just remember there is no comparison between this and what you would see on Broadway, in Toronto or Peoria at Route 24, Junction 8, for that matter. The movie could only leave you disappointed. It is entertaining especially if you are forgiving of Streep and Brosnan not being singers.

Thank you, Christian, Gabriella, Samuel Adam, and Emmanuel.

Uncle Ed

For Barrie Bracken.

I LOVE this movie.  The characters are terrific and the cinematography is breathtaking.  The songs will stay with you. The story is adorable. Get it and watch it and watch it and watch it again and again.  Guaranteed you'll love it too.

I bought this movie after seeing it in the theater. I do not like musicals
but when I saw this with 3 of my 5 sisters we had a blast .  We were up dancing in our seats . Our arms and hands never stopped moving .

 Go see this or buy it !!!
 Pat Keller
We saw it at the theatre and just had to have it on DVD. One of my all time favorite movies.  Meryl Streep is fantastic.

Great movie.  I know...many will say the stage play is better...but I have no possibility of seeing that production.  Love the scenery...love the music....a great story.  Very well done.  Need something to raise your spirits?  Watch this!

The item was ordered on 12/8, supposedly shipped on 12/14, and as of today (January 7th) had not arrived.  I was asked by e-mail to rate the product, but all I can report is that it is not here yet.

Amazon is replacing it with a new DVD, to be delivered tomorrow, so hopefully I'll be able to review it later this week.

I've never seen the original stage version of Mamma Mia and for no other reason that the idea simply didn't appeal to me.  I took a chance on the movie version for one reason and one reason only:  Its cast.  With the possible exception of Pierce Brosnan, I love all of these actors, especially Meryl Streep, Julie Walters, Colin Firth and Christine Baranski, whose previous work I've greatly admired.  This is not so terrible a film as some people have stated.  All I can say to those who love to stamp every movie they don't like with the headline "worst film I've ever seen" is that frankly, if this inoffensive little concoction is the worst movie you've ever seen, then you're an extremely lucky movie goer, because I've seen some dogs that make Mamma Mia look like "A Man For All Seasons."  The main problem I had with this movie was with my own personal inability to separate the songs from the original artist.  To me it was like watching the ultimate chick flick with some pretty bad renditions of ABBA songs used as a narrative device.  If you're not a longtime ABBA fan and are not too familiar with these classic and first rate examples of pop music, it'll probably not make much difference to you who sings them and how they're sung, but in my head I just kept hearing the originals and couldn't help but feel they were the sole glue holding together an otherwise trite and boring story about young love, female camaraderie and rediscovering the joys of love.  To boot, the script is threadbare and makes no impact whatsoever on the viewer.  In short, fantastic songs, badly sung (for the most part) and used in a really mediocre vehicle.  I'll say this though, everyone seemed to be enjoying themselves, the location is awesome and it's a harmless enough little movie that the ladies, especially, will like.  The men, though, will no doubt be rolling their eyes and checking their watches begging to be put out of their misery.  I know I was.  Wholly forgettable in spite of its best intentions and first rate cast.

"Mamma Mia" is thoroughly entertaining! As you watch and listen to the scenery and music, you'll want to get up and dance.  Meryl Streep shows that she is the consummate actress.  She can do it all! It's the kind of movie you'll want to see over and over because it makes you feel good.
This is a great movie.  I love doing business with Amazon.  They ship really fast.

Of course I loved this feel good movie, which I had seen on the big screen, a better way to see this type of movie.  We hadn't gotten very far into the movie when the DVD started skipping.  It settled down a little later and my daughter and I enjoyed the rest.  No one can beat Meryl Streep at ANY type of movie.  If you haven't seen this and are a fan of musicals, this movie is for you.
I have seen Mamma Mia on broadway 2 times and the movie is just another way of being able to watch it over and over!  Great movie!

A young woman, raised by a single parent mother, prepares for her upcoming wedding on a Greek island. Upon finding her mother's old diary, she discovers that her unknown father could have been one of three men. She invites all three to attend her wedding, on the juvenile assumption that she will "know" her father when she meets him. Of course she tells neither her mother nor the three men of her plans. The plot is similar to the much better "Buona Sera, Mrs. Campbell" (1968).

The story is woven around a large number of songs from the 70s musical group ABBA. The film's shortcoming is that there are simply too many songs and not enough story. The thinly-plotted story is merely an excuse to sing and dance, which is why I called it a revue. Consequently, we learn very little about the three men, surely the past lives and personalities of her potential fathers would be of great interest to the girl. All we learn about them is that one is a sort of adventure-travel writer, and the other two are suit-wearing businessmen - one of whom is gay, the other divorced.

Acting, from both youthful and veteran actors is at the flamboyant, gushy, everything is a crisis, teenage level. The singing and dancing are good, though not the original ABBA recordings. If you liked "High School Musical" you will probably like this one too.

I cannot believe all the 5 star reviews. I was looking forward to this movie because EVERYONE LOVED IT! I guess I am in the minority, because the movie had no plot plus the singing is really bad. Meryl Streep, a great actress, is not right for this part as is most of the cast. It is almost like the cast is having a ongoing party and forget they are making a movie.
Mamma Mia review.  What a good movie !!  We have always liked musicals and this one did not disappoint.

Fabulous, fun, great acting, sing and dance along. Movies like this are few and far between. I was never an ABBA fan but I love the way these songs are presented. Great for all ages. Meryl Streep is at her best. Very, very well cast and choreographed.

Excellent movie with good bonus features. Fun to watch!
Received very quick delivery by Amazon.

I saw this movie in the theater and loved it, but enjoyed it even more at home.  Smart, witty, beautifully scenic and brilliantly acted.

Meryl Streep amazing, Christine Biranski and Julie Walters sheer delights as the girlfriends.  Excellent casting and highly enjoyable.  Great charisma.

The men, gorgeous to look at, but not singers, so be prepared, made it all the more enjoyable and realistic.  Where else can you feast your eyes on Colin Firth and Pierce Brosnan together, every woman's dream. Watch the credits, a really good time.

The youngsters, wonderfully talented but the adults delightfully steal the show.

A really enjoyable experience all around, of course ABBA being the "Winner That Takes It All."

This movie has easily become one of my favorite movies EVER!! I have always loved musicals and after seeing Hairspray in theaters I decided to make it a priority to see all movie musicals on the big screen!! After seeing this I am just as sure that musicals are just getting better.

This movie showcases outstanding performances from all involved!! Whether it be Meryl Streep, Christine Baranski, and Julie Walters belting out "Dancing Queen", Pierce Brosnan, Colin Firth, and Stellen Skarsgard singing the brezzy "Our Last Summer", or Meryl simply singing the beautiful ballad "Slipping Through My Fingers" this film is sure to please everyone!!

I love cheesy movies and a fair number of musicals BUT this has to be a joke.  This movie is breaking records for 2008???  There are maybe two songs that faired an okay from me-the rest I was cringing every time the actors opened their mouths.  I love Meryl and I doubt that I'll ever be able to prop her back on the pedestal I had her on after this.  This is bad.  This is a very bad film and I couldn't dare recommend this to my worst enemy.

Chick flick!  Get a group of women together, turn on the "sing along" function and have loads of laughs!!

Meryl Streep, Christine Baranski, Pierce Bronsan, et.al.-- God Bless 'em, their joy in making this musical is transparent and infectious.  It's also a beautiful film -- the scenery is fantastic.  The saturated color from the opening on through is perfect for this genre.  "Mamma Mia" is a gift of fun and good cheer.  Enjoy!

My wife and I tried to watch this movie, and We couldn't believe the sexual dialogue and inuendo. DONT EVER try to watch this movie with kids around. We thought it would be an upbeat movie with some great Abba songs. It must have been written by a Cosmo editor. One of the worst movies I have ever started to watch. Save your money, and your time.

A cold, gloomy, nasty afternoon in a hotel in Canada. Five hours until warm-up time in the orchestra pit. Take a walk? Ni modo, Quasimodo! Rent a flick? Why not!

You'll have to believe me that I have no prior ABBA consciousness, despite the fact that I spent half my childhood in Sweden. I was in Mediterranean and Caribbean lands when they 'conquered' the Anglophone pop music world. I heard or read the name. Honestly, I thought they were another 'heavy metal' or Swedish vampyr band. I had no idea what they looked or sounded like. My wife tells me now that we danced to ABBA covers at innumerable family weddings over the past 25 years, but I never pay much attention when I'm trying to shake my booty without looking as dorky as I feel. Okay, do I suddenly love their music now, after seeing/hearing "Mamma Mia!"? Well... it's bouncy and sweet, but no way will it displace Dufay or Scarlatti on my iPod. ABBA is musically as corny as their costumes -- a 1970s period piece. Apologies to their fans, and to all Swedes everywhere. Hurray for IKEA! Hurray for ABBA! Sweden needs all the export credits it can get.

And now the movie review! The most artful thing about Mamma Mia is the integration of the songs and chorus-line numbers into the melodrama. Reviewer JP, whose recommendation of this film was responsible for me picking it up, commented on the "Greek Chorus" of Greeks serving as a human and musical backdrop for the jet set cast of English speakers. She's right, and it was effective. I'm so far out of touch with Broadway that I thought JP's praise of the music/drama blend sounded just like Bollywood. I've seen a lot of Bollywood films. I urged JP to have a look at Lagaan, one of my favs. Bottom line? Mamma Mia is almost... almost... as artful at squeezing into and out of musical extravaganzas as Bollywood, though the ABBA songs are less appealing. Keep practicing, USA! You'll catch up with India some day.

The story? Mildly amusing, absolutely predictable, jolly enough to keep me watching. Merle Streep looks remarkably like my sister, or vice versa. I get a kick out of the resemblance, and I was delighted to see my 'sister' having so much fun in a role. Streep's enjoyment of her own feeble singing was infectious. I was tickled to watch my usually dour countryman, Stellan Skarsgrd, try to act zany. Zaniness is not intuitive for Swedes. Stellan and I look a lot alike, also, though I'm in better shape. I took a sardonic pleasure in watching him look hopelessly dorky when he danced. At the other extreme, the spark-plug friend of Mamma - I didn't catch her name, the tall one who can really sing and dance - is obviously a real Broadway-ite, and carried the film at times when others were looking vague about their blocking. The young'uns were cast for their looks, and look they did. Some credit has to go to the Greek Islands for the exuberance of the film also; I've spent time on Mykonos, Skiathos, Santorini, etc., and my own nostalgia for those times mixed into the characters of the three middle-aged guys who 'came back wishing they'd never left.' Too bad, now that I think of it, that there wasn't any Greek music at this Greek wedding!

Five stars? Hey, just like it says on the box: "a hilarious, rousing & joyous celebration!"

Not much to say about this one.  It's too musical for my own tastes, I reocommended it to my 17 year old daughter.  The bursting out in song at the beginning turned me off.  The movie just didn't work for me. I have heard others say good things about it so I rate it a 3.

I've read, listened and snickered at all the reasons for not liking the movie. The weak voices of some of the actors attached, the nonsensical plot, etcetera, but at the end of the day, I simply couldn't. Intellectual snobbery aside, all of the cast were having such a bloody good time on screen that all the arguments were laid to rest.  In an age where good comedies get no awards, where musicals are picked apart and lambasted for not 'making sense' (as if any instance of people singing and dancing spontaneously would EVER make logical sense) and only the bleakest of the bleak movies/performances get accolades and award recognition, how can it be wrong to just want to smile, shake your head and enjoy this movie, regardless of the many reasons to not do so?

We all know the major players, but I think Amanda Seyfried (who has also been an standout on television in "Veronica Mars" and "Big House") should be commended for her acting AND singing ability.  Her sweet rendition of "I Have a Dream" was spectacular and her many other interpretations throughout this movie more than made up for any other musical shortcomings.

After being unceremoniously passed over for the film version of "Evita," the incomparable Meryl Streep finally showcases her singing and dancing talents in "Mamma Mia!" Her sparkling presence makes this lightweight confection more pleasurable than it has any right to be. Forget the threadbare plot - not to mention Pierce Brosnan's painful vocal stylings - and enjoy the rare sight of Meryl belting out the ABBA songbook.

I don't like musicals, but this is different. Love, fun, romance - everything is in this movie. Above all it is a touching movie for me because last year I lost my mother and Sohie says 'I love you mum' when everyhing goes wrong. Anyway, if you'd like to be happy for some time, you must see this movie.

Okay, I was younger when ABBA was singing and dancing their way into our hearts with their great songs. Now that I'm older, well the songs are still in my heart. I work out--at home of course--to the beat of ABBA. It is simply impossible to find music this good, IMO. They say imitation is the best form of flattery, and the music in this movie is good, not great. The acting is another matter: it is great. Meryl has never been better. Can you imagine 007 in a musical? Hilarious. Yes, it is, IMO, more of a romantic comedy than strictly a musical. The story line was fantastically entertaining. Combine that with the nostalga of ABBA music, throw in some premium actors, and you have a hit.

I admit that it seemed silly at times, and I had to laugh at Pierce Brosnan's singing (but what a great, courageous attempt). I don't often look at the director's remarks, but these remarks were highly interesting as to the filming and recording. Did I mention the karoke sing-along complete with words to the songs? Yep, gotta love it.

Last, I admit I was moved to tears with the combo of music, acting, and story line. The young Sophia (Amanda) reminded me of my first love, full of life and zesto. Her singing skills were simply outstanding.

If you haven't guessed I highly recommend you see this feature. Give yourself a sentimental opportunity and you may find this is one of the best you will ever experience.

I loved this movie, it really made me laugh, and cry, and feel good. I haven't enjoyed a movie as much as this one in a long time.  Look at how much fun the actors are having, and who wouldn't, shooting in a location like that, with the story line and music to work with. It must have been a hoot to work on that production, and that spills over to the audience!

I must admit up front that I didn't enjoy the Broadway show from a story perspective but the music was great. I watched the dvd not expecting anything more from the story but was looking forward to a first class rendition of the songs. The actors and acting are so disconcerting it will be virtually impossible to watch in its entirety for many folks. The vocals are generally horrible and to see Meryl Streep in this movie is like watching a good actor on the Love Boat or Surreal Life...you know their career is over.
Unfortunately, I can't recommend this movie from any point of view and could imagine that even great fans of ABBA would find this embarrassing.

Alrighty... there are probably very few musicals that I ever liked... and I did like Grease. The sequal to Grease I thought was a flop and THIS movie "Momma Mia" does even worse. I'm sorry... this is the worst review I have ever given any movie... normally I like most movies and can appreciate them for what they are... heck, I even liked "Battlefield Earth" with John Travolta even though the reviews said it sucked.
Anyways... the likes of Meryl Streep and Pierce Brosnan and of course ABBA are the only saving qualities to this movie. It's unfortunate that such a goofy movie needs to be associated with ABBA. I was starting to think that the movie was a tribute to ABBA since they tried to squeeze in as many songs as possible. More song than dialog and character building. Every one was so in love with the character played by Meryl Streep even tho she probably slept around with a million guys and no one knew who the father of the "daughter getting married" was. She probably ran out of room in her diary to mention so many guys. Sorry... the premise of this movie is silly, and glorifying it all makes it worse. My last thoughts for the movie was everyone was pumped up on estrogen and this movie is responsible for the girlification of America... haha. Ok, seriously... that crossed my mind. I became quite critical of the movie while watching it... I didn't really enjoy it so much... but I did watch it end to end.

Who'd of thought that ABBA songs could be so operatic? Certainly not me! The fact that I hadn't seen the stage-play (by the same name) probably added to my surprise. Being no fan of that Swedish rock group of the 70s and 80s, I was doubly surprised to find myself enjoying this film so much. In no small measure was my enjoyment thanks to the all-star cast, no doubt, but also how well incorporated the songs were within the story. The story is worthy of a Shakespearean comedy with high confusion, paternal bonds in question, and lady-love finding its way into the audiences heart in unusual ways. The story, this time, revolves around Sophie (Amanda Seyfried, House, M.D.) and her desire to find her true father before her wedding. Stumbling upon her mother's diary, Sophie finds three candidates that might be her dad. Her mother Donna (Meryl Streep, The Devil Wears Prada) has no idea that her daughter has invited three of her former loves to the wedding. And when they arrive, paternal sparks go a-flying, as do the flickers of old romances. Harry (Colin Firth) comes to the wedding out of fear that he'd done something and then left it undone (i.e., not properly fathering his daughter). Bill (Stellan Skarsgard, Pirates of the Caribbean - At World's End) comes simply because he's curious. But Sam (Pierce Brosnan, The Matador) arrives with a burning love-gone-by for Donna. And when Donna finds out all three of these old flames have arrived for the wedding, chaos ensues ...mixed with some toe-tapping music (Gah! Toe-tapping to ABBA!). The other element to the story are two old work friends of Donna's (they were a trio of singers at one time) who arrive for the wedding and find Donna in a frazzled state. Rosie (Julie Walters, Becoming Jane) is the active and playful one with plenty of spunk, while Tanya (Christine Baranski) is the sexual over-achiever who has to fight off the advances of a few young island boys. Surprises abound as the movie winds down. One person comes out of the closet, while two others find love (even though one is running away from any possible commitment). Donna herself might find love in the arms of one of those old flames. And Sophie's wedding gets a change of venue. One of the final songs on the track ("Take a Chance on Me") is extremely funny and well thought-out. And as the credits roll, there's some laugh-out-loud moments as we get to watch Colin Firth try to dance in a skin-tight, sequined outfit (along with the other main players in the film). The final positive note for this movie has to be that the director Phyllida Lloyd was also responsible for MAMMA MIA's huge stage production success, and her translation of it from stage to silver screen was exceptionally well-rendered. This one's a surprisingly good film, even for those folks who aren't into ABBA.

I didn't know Meryl Streep and Pierce Bronson could sing!  That was a nice surprise.

This was a really fun musical with some very zany, unique and creative dances and scenes and plots.  I LOVED the scene of a bunch of guys doing a dance on the dock with flippers.  I laughed many times during this musical and it was such a joyous experience watching it for the first time.  It was also fun to hear the old ABBA songs I haven't heard for years, and loved so much as a kid.

For a musical tho, I was surprised that they didn't cast singers with stronger vocals.  They were passable for sure, but the vocals weren't excellent, which you usually do find in musicals.  But, that also may have added to the quirkiness of this musical.

No wonder people are raving over this film!!! It's a musical for sure. It's a comedy--part of the time. It's dramatic--some of the time. And it is entertaining ALL of the time! I laughed! I cried! I cheered! I sang! I love this film--and the best part was Meryl Streep dancing and singing in all parts--whether as part of the story or in her trio.

Everyone was delightful in his/her role. It is true--the singers are not trained professionals--they are more like real people singing in real situations. OK, most people don't blurt out in song, but wouldn't you rather have Meryl sing her own songs than have her lip sync as Audrey Hepburn did in "My Fair Lady?"

Or to see and hear Pierce Brosnan sing so painfully in his role? His struggle lent credence to his role as a once-heartbroken young man who finds himself 20 years later in a place make amends. His singing was sweet and heartfelt.

Or Julie Waters' show-stopping number toward the end of the film. "Take a Chance on Me!" Indeed! Or the concept of the Greek chorus (you get it?!!)--Greek chorus, made up of local villagers in just the right places for the numbers. Especially the women following Meryl/Donna scene.

Mamma Mia--my mamma is known, but who is my dad? Sophie finds her mother's journal the summer she was conceived only to learn that her dad could be one of three men. How this is resolved is one of the great moments of the movie. It's a Greek wedding under the summer sun with a touch of Shakespeare's Midsummer Night's Dream of magic and confusion. As in the Bard's play things are set back in order, maybe a new order by movie's end.

To get there the viewer will experience a brouhaha of ABBA melodies (the musical is based on their hits) rousing, funny, and serious. When Meryl/Donna sings to Pierce just before the wedding, my heart broke with hers. Wow, that was as powerful a scene as anything she's done dramatically in other roles.

But enough. I want to finish watching the Feature Commentary in which Director Phyllida Lloyd explains each scene: where, how, purpose. I must confess that I didn't know outdoor scenes are often shot in studio simulations.

In case you are wondering, I am in the Camp of "Mamma Mia!" enthusiasts. This is Review #178.

There aren't many movies made now that make you HAPPY. This is one that does. It's just a delight to listen to and watch. The actors are having a great time, the music is addictive and the scenery gorgeous. Sit back and enjoy!

I've been an ABBA fan since the release of their first record. I have all the original record albums that I am little by little converting to disc. Never have I seen their music better represented.
  I have never though been a fan of Meryl Streep....this movie changed my opinion of her as an actress. I wasn't aware until recently that she could sing & was very pleased to see her in this role.
  This is a wonderful "Feel Good" movie to be watched again & again.
The music numbers seem to be written around the story instead of the other way. Some of the songs are campy, but that adds to the fun of the movie. Others, like Streep's rendition of "The Winner Takes It All" can be heart wrenching. My favorite part of the movie is the scene built around the song "Voulez Vous"...also the scene with the song "Slipping Through My Fingers."
  Buy this for yourself & watch it multiple times...you will smile, laugh & maybe even cry, but you will not be disapointed.

This may be one of the worst films I've ever seen -- even just for fun, it's just plain embarrassing! If you like/love ABBA's music (which I do), get their CDs.  If you like/love all these truly wonderful actors (I do!), watch them in something else!!! I just hope they were paid well and had a ball on location.  There is no plot, no script, and no, Pierce Brosnan, fine man and fine actor that he is, can't carry a tune in a ten-barrel bucket. I just kept waiting for this to be OVER! Glad I checked it out of the library instead of paying anything to see it. The best thing about it is the end titles.  Don't waste your time -- if you're looking for fluff, for fun, there are many other movies worth the time!

Maybe it's a generational thing, but this was a fabulously entertaining movie. Camera angles, Peirce Brosnan's singing, blah, blah, blah... Buy it, turn down the lights, turn up the volume, pour yourself a bottle of wine and enjoy the movie.

Are there better singers in the world? Yeah, maybe. Are there better actors for this show? Likely not. Meryl Streep is simply wonderful, she carries the character of Donna just wonderfully. Watching Amanda Seyfried make the transition from "Mean Girls" to Sophie here is entrancing, and her singing is inspiring.

Christine Baranski is simply hysterical in everything she is in and Mamma Mia! is no exception!

High point? Meryl Streep singing "The Winner Takes It All," how she manages to make it such a powerful performance without being ABBA is simply a testament to her ability as an actress. Buy it. Enjoy it. And watch it again and again and again.

After seeing the movie when it first came out, I was dying to get the DVD to find out why they made changes to the stage version. The commentary from director Phyllida Lloyd is extremely insightful and explains why they had to remove "The Name of the Game" and shortened some of the songs (though I wish they would have kept it in and shortened the "When All Is Said And Done" wedding reception number!). Surprisingly, none of the male actors were hired with knowledge that they could sing - so they were all nervous of the challenge of singing and dancing at the same time. I wish they had done a second commentary with the cast, but then they probably wouldn't have been able to release this before Christmas.

There aren't too many deleted scenes (mainly of the 3 guys at the beginning reading letters), or many outtakes (the Making of video has more outtakes), but overall the 2nd DVD is well worth having in your library. Buy the 2 disc version and you won't be disappointed!!!

It was a great musical, and frankly great for women, but as a guy, I will never get it. I guess there is freedom in musicals unlike any other media, where you can act silly and no one will diminish it, or criticize it.

I was impressed by the cast (and having never been able to see the play) willing to "Take a Chance" on "Mamma Mia!"  I am so glad I did.  I rarely purchase DVD's to own unless the film REALLY impresses me in some way.  This one did.  Not only does it bring back memories from my high school days (YES!  I was an ABBA fan!) but it was just plain fun!  It looked as if the actors were having a fabulous time and so did I!  Uplifting and entertaining - what a pleasant surprise!

Oh. God. Make. The. Pain. Stop.......

Okay, it wasn't the worse film I've seen, but it definitely ranks as one of the worst vocally presented musicals ever. Ever. Outside of the wonderfully talented young voice of Amanda Seyfried, I haven't heard singing this bad on film since Jack Nicholson in Tommy or George Burns in Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band. Even though Meryl Streep should be given the "Best Try" award for looking like she was having a good time while not showing embarrassment, "singers" like Pierce Brosnan sound like they were soulless barking dogs and needed to be put out of their misery. Sure, visually the movie is a fun romp, but if I hear Meryl either sigh, cry, or moan during each song again, I swear I'm gonna buy me a chalkboard and scratch away. I find it hard to believe the Broadway play it's based on is so huge, but then again it's based on music that helped define a generation...just not mine. Heed this warning: unless you are a bonafide ABBA fanatic or simply "ghey" for musicals, do yourself a favor and rent Across The Universe again than to put yourself through this. GACK!
(RedSabbath Rating:4.5/10)

I hadn't really heard much about this movie before seeing it other than seeing a trailer for it and knowing some of the critics didn't care much for it. I thought it was just fantastic! It's one of those movies just make you feel good. Whatever they said was wrong with the filming, singing or direction may have been true, but for me it just worked. It made me want to get up off the couch and dance and sing along. The scenery was absolutely gorgeous. The costuming was appropriate, the acting superb. (What's not to like about Meryl Streep?) The Abba music was wonderful and the singing was...well, they sing like the rest of us, and there was a certain charm to that. Mama Mia! I have to give this movie a two thumbs up. I found a Wii game that lets me dance and sing a bunch of the great songs from this movie and get some exercise in the process. ABBA You Can Dance

Can I just say that the one word that sums this movie up is FUN! It wasn't great by any stretch of the imagination but I loved just getting some chocolate ice cream and watching it. It was just like a hot fudge sundae on a sunny day. I've always loved Meryl Streep and she was great as usual. Goofy movie, yes but worth watching to pass some really enjoyable time.

This rates as the worst movie I have ever seen. Shallow idiocy. My friend who invited me to see this movie with him apologized for choosing such a bad flick. I was only able to watch it all the way through because I did not wish to hurt my date's feelings. I don't know if I will ever be that polite again. Such a mindless extravaganza was painful to watch.

I don't care what the critics say, this movie is just fun!  The fact that the actors actually sang is awesome, that rarely happens anymore and I applaud them all.  If you like ABBA music you will LOVE the movie.

"Mamma Mia! The Movie"  is based on the long-running Broadway play.  Its thin plot was conceived to tie together a catalogue of ABBA songs.  Donna (Meryl Streep) is an independent, single mother who owns a small hotel on a picture-perfect Greek island.  Her daughter, Sophie (Amanda Seyfried), is about to be married and Donna has invited to the wedding two lifelong friends from her one-time singing group, Donna and the Dynamos -- multi-divorcee Tanya (Christine Baranski) and practical, no-nonsense Rosie (Julie Walters).  Sophie has secretly invited three guests of her own.  Longing to discover the identity of her father so he can walk her down the aisle, she brings back three men from Donna's past to the Mediterranean paradise they visited 20 years earlier -- Bill (Stellan Skarsgard), Sam (Pierce Brosnan), and Harry (Colin Firth).
 Streep's Donna is far afield from any role the actress has played before.  It's light, almost buoyant, as Donna sings her heart out, dances on a pier, or looks mortified when she meets her three beaus from decades past.  The songs by ABBA include "Dancing Queen," "S.O.S.," "Take a Chance on Me," and "Money, Money, Money."  When you finish watching the film, the songs will remain in your head for hours, if not days.  You'll have to decide if that's a good or a bad thing.  Both Baranski, with her trademark deadpan delivery, and Walters, with take-no-prisoners energy, provide ample comic relief.  The two-disc Special Edition contains a making-of documentary, a detailed featurette on the staging of one musical number ("Lay All Your Love On Me"), a music video, deleted scenes and outtakes, and a digital copy of the movie.

Love this movie! Get it, watch it - bet it makes you smile & laugh out loud, and maybe even 'dance out loud" as I did (twice so far).
Just Great Fun start to finish.
And the credits are even MORE fun!

I thought I had seen everything that movies had to offer until I saw Mamma Mia! last night on DVD. What's new is seeing Meryl Streep unwind and let it all fly -- singing, dancing, acting -- well, we all knew she could act with the best, but who knew she could sing and dance as well? A great team of supporting actors and actresses, all of whom could sing (Pierce Brosnan excepted). Actually, I enjoyed Brosnan's performances, including his singing. Sometimes a little less polish and a little more realism carries the day. Brosnan could always deliver a line, and he has some key ones in this movie. I thought the big production numbers were very entertaining. I even enjoyed the plot line, although there were some cruel twists at the end. I won't spoil the movie by revealing the twists I didn't like, but they soured me enough to knock off what would otherwise have been a five star rating.

As usual, it is best to ignore the professional movie critics. Something happens when you take money for your movie reviews, and it is not good. My wife and I enjoyed this fine, entertaining movie. I thought most of the cinematography was very good to excellent. The scene that a lot of people seem to be complaining about features a pretty amazing performance by Meryl Streep. That was captivating enough to draw my attention away from some supposed faults in the cinematography. Oh well, too busy enjoying the movie to be hypercritical. I think you will be, too.

I was a huge ABBA fan as a teenager. I have all their music and still enjoy listening to them. I even liked the stage play Mamma Mia.

However...

the movie stinks! First of all, why on earth did the filmmakers cast actors who cannot sing? And if they had to cast these actors, at least let them lip sync. I adore Meryl Streep but she is not that talented when it comes to singing. Pierce Brosnan is so atrocious that I had to fast-forward his numbers. Ditto for everyone else in this movie (well Christine Baranski is not too bad). I don't see how anyone could appreciate Abba's music after hearing it here.

The only thing I did enjoy was the cinematography and the incredibly colorful Mediterranean setting.

Ignore the critics.  The old adage that "Those who CAN, DO; those who CAN'T, CRITICIZE," fits like a glove here.  I seldom go to a movie theatre, but--after seeing the Broadway show--I just HAD to see the film.  The fact that Meryl Streep sings and acts in the film is just like waking up and winning the filmdom lottery!  So, the movie is so fabulous, that I just HAD to have the 2 disc edition DVD.  All those extras!  Yummy!  Chick Flick be d---ed!  My husband, who refused to see the show or go to the movie theatre, enjoyed the heck out of the DVD.  (This is the guy who watches Outlaw Josie Wales every time it's on TV--so often that I almost have the dialogue memorized.  You wouldn't want to fail to enjoy missing that!)  So, do yourself a huge favor.  Get Mamma Mia!

Mama mia what have I done to deserve this? Well, at least I can return it.
I had high hopes and was excited to watch this film and felt like I just wasted my life.
Dont get me wrong, I love showtunes but this one was a HUGE let down.
I like only the very few ABBA songs used, and the others to me weren't my favorite.
The singing was not the greatest either. I won't pick the cons out b/c most negative reviews explain everything that I didn't like about this film.
Plus its total chickflicks, I don't like chickflicks and Im a chick. I'll stick with ALW, Moulin rouge, the marraige of figaro, sweeney todd and repo, thankyou. At least with the few crappy songs in those shows, I leave happy. ^_^
Also it beats me buying overpriced tickets to the actual show and be disappointed. ^_^

When I first went to see this flick with my better half, I really didn't care for it. I'm an avid music lover of all genres other than heavy metal and improvisational jazz (I know I'm not alone in that) and was fairly critical of the amateur-grade singing by decidedly professional-grade actors. Hairspray nailed this approach. Mamma Mia! doesn't. However, having purchased the soundtrack shortly after seeing the film in theaters, I've found myself listening to the album from time to time over the past few months, and you know what? I'm now starting to like it precisely FOR its fresh amateur qualities. Couple the now familiar versions of the songs with this startlingly gorgeous and colorful Blu-ray release, and suddenly I find myself punching up 8/10 and 4/5's for this thing. It's just good fun, and that's not bad.

Warning to those with older Receivers. This Blu-ray disk only has a DTS audio soundtrack in English. If you have a Receiver, like I do, that only decodes Dolby Digital 5.1, there is no audio output.

The rest of this review is for the clueless producers of this Blu-ray disk. Obviously they have learned nothing from the costly lost sales of the war with HD-DVD. People like me are not going to buy an expensive new Receiver just to play a particular movie on Blu-ray. Especially with six audio formats to cover and perhaps more to come! I will rent this movie on DVD and wait for the audio wars to end. Since Blu-ray has plenty of capacity, I do not see any reason why an English Dolby 5.1 soundtrack could not be included to ensure backwards compatibility. Particularly since Dolby 5.1 is already provided on this disk in other languages. From reading various blogs and reviews, I know I am not the only potential lost sale.

I love ABBA. I love Meryl Streep. I love music. I love my best friend who recommended this movie to me.

How will I ever tell my best friend the truth, after having ordered and watched this pitiful production.

All the way through,I couldn't wait for it to be over. I have rarely "ever" felt this way about a film.

Don't waste your money. It is a travesty. Nothing redeemable. Beyond stupid and boring. Very sad to say.

ZzZzZz

I got it for Christmas and watched it twice in a row to catch everything I missed the first time!

The only thing I am sorry about it that the version I got is the one disk so I don't get to see the bloopers....really wanted to see those!

As far as the poor reviews of Pierce Brosnan....I have heard MUCH worse!!  I am surprised that no one has mentioned Christine Beranski, she is great as usual!

For parents of young kids....I would watch it first to make sure you want your kids to see the couple of frames that may not be appropriate for them (maybe distract them for those 10 seconds because the rest of the movie is great!).

I absolutely adored this movie in theaters and am a big fan.  I was very excited my sister got this for me for Christmas but the transfer to fullscreen is just horrible.  There is so much "pan and scan" that its distracting and half the time someone will say his or her line and you can even see them say it because they got cut off off-screen.  Even my non-movie-buff friends said it distracted them.  Get the widescreen instead.

The movie was definitely over the top where the acting and plot were concerned, but what I think a lot of people forget is that this musical was designed for the stage, so in order to capture people's attention for a stage production, it has to be over the top.

The only thing that really had me wincing was Pierce Brosnan's singing, however, I don't think he has ever claimed to be a singer.  My thought is that they could probably have cast someone who could sing into that role, but aside from that, he acted in his part well.

Overall the movie is very entertaining and worth seeing at least once.  Just take it for what it is and don't expect to be blown away by great vocal performances, great acting or even a good plot.  No one ever said a movie had to be believable to be entertaining, right?

This musical was taken to the wide screen, mainly with actors, rather than singers. Meryl Streep might not be the best singer in the world, but wow! She gives all her soul, and the most powerful interpretation of "Winner Takes it All" It is great to see middle aged women having so much fun, and handsome actors in glittery suits, dancing and singing, very funny!!!

Nearly indescribable with the English language, how awful this movie is.  I won't belabor what other reviewers have said so well; but, for my own two cents, the thing that most destroys this piece is CASTING.  Meryl Streep is insane beyond belief as the mother of the bride.  Grandmother, maybe; she looks so old in this film that her very first appearance on screen ruins everything before and after.  Streep's face looks like a leather glove with two slits for eyes; apparently, too much cosmetic surgery has tightened her skin until it has pulled her eyes back into small slots.  I became a slightly nauseous at having to look at that face on-screen over the course of the film.
Streep's ancient look made everything else absurd- her former lovers look like her children in comparison, and from the apparent age of her "daughter" in the film, her character would have had to have given birth in her mid-70's.
I am with many other reviewers who marvel at how writers and directors can take top notch actors, music, and scenery and throw it all away, creating a horrific and, if there is any mercy in the world, a quickly forgettable moment in cinema madness.

Having never been to an ABBA concert or owned a record or seen the play, I love this film.  It is good natured enjoyment.  There is enough naughtiness to keep it from being bland.  Sure most of the singing is more about acting then voice.  This is fantasy after all.  Meryl Streep is just wonderful as always.  I keep going back to the word fun.  It's hard to see this film without smiling.  That is what this is all about.  The extras are outstanding.  Get some friends together,  have a drink and sing along.

I love movie musicals. This is one of the worst movies (of any kind) I have ever seen. Watching and listening to Pierce Brosnan in this movie is painful.  Rent before you waste your money on this one.
Couple friends and I bought the movie. It was one of the best movies I have ever seen!!! The scenery is incredible, the music just picks you up. You cant help to smile from start to finish!

This movie was horrible, the acting was just downright cheesy! If it hadn't been for my grandma wanting to see this, I would have never thought twice about it. Infact, just seeing the preview, I said to my boyfriend "I Never Want to see that!" Well, I guess I jinxed myself! But, it really didn't do anything for me!

LOTS OF FUN ... BRINGS BACK LOTS OF MEMORIES WITH THE ABBA SONGS. THIS WILL BE ANOTHER ZANADU. CRITICS WILL PUT IT DOWN, VIEWERS WILL DOG ON IT BUT PEOPLE WILL CONTINUE TO WATCH IT OVER & OVER AGAIN RATHER IT'S ON TV OR AT THE VODEO STORE FOR RENTAL. IT WILL MAKE YOUR TOES TAP AND HAVE YOU DANCING IN YOUR CHAIR. IT IS THE FIRST MUSICAL IN YEARS THAT SHOULD BE WATCHED BY ALL. PLEASE RENT OR BUY IT AND ENJOY!!!
Mama Mia  - What a great movie.  You can watch it over and over again like Pretty Woman and Ferris Bueller's Day Off.  Two of my favorites.

...or James Bond sings! The film adaptation of the smash Mamma Mia! The Musical Based on the Songs of ABBA, has a lot going for it. The least of which is the immensely likable songs of ABBA, which anchor the movie with familiarity. The scenery is gorgeous and the cast is packed with exuberance and cheer. Then again, at 59, Meryll Streep steals the film with her presence as the former girl-group singer retired to an island resort. Packed with good cheer, great music and eye catching dance numbers, "Mamma Mia" is as frothy and glittery as the foam riding the tops of an island wave. But it's also just about as substantial. As Donna, Streep just shimmers. Her gal-pals Tanya (Christine Baranski) and Rosie (Julie Waters) each have scene stealing moments. When Tanya lets loose on a flirtatious younger man with "Does Your Mother Know," it's one of the funniest bits in the movie. As Sophie, Amanda Seyfried carries her songs probably better than anyone here. Even as she is the focal point of "Mamma Mia," the story is ultimately Streep's. It is Donna's crisis of parenthood (the flimsy set-up where Sophie invites her three probable fathers to her wedding) that forms the crux of the movie. The musical numbers spin off in all direction, not always conducive to the plot. Be that as it may, we watched the "sing-along" version of the film is great fun, and Streep's version of "The Winner Takes It All" is a show-stopper. I also defy you not to sing along to either "Dancing Queen" or "Waterloo" (done as a campy finale with the principals in ABBA period costumes). Also noted, none of the male leads can sing worth a lick, although the story that Brosnan didn't know he was being cast in a musical is pretty funny (he was approached with the offer to play a male lead in a movie with Meryll Streep, then was told what the movie was AFTER he accepted). But if you accept "Mamma Mia" for what it is, a big hunk of feel-good fun, you won't come away disappointed. Now where is that Movie adaptation of We Will Rock You?

This is a total waste of money. Meryl Streep flails as she dances, and the singing looks like bad lip sinc. The acting is very bad and they could have done a better job on Meryl's sloppy, red-nosed complection, especially when she is "upset". The set and backdrop look very plastic and unreal in appearance. It is a "Grease" wannabe that falls flat on its face. Can't believe all the good reviews.

Usually I don't like musicals, but this movie is a gem. I haven't seen the stage production or even the film in a theater, but I'm thoroughly enjoying Mamma Mia at home. Great cast, great scenery, and none of it to be taken too seriously. The extras on the disk are good, features about making the movie, commentary by the director, etc. The quality is excellent and I'm so glad I switched to Blu-ray in time for this release.

Just watched this from Netflix. I was raised by parents that enjoyed and believed that as children we should be exposed to music in all forms and that included musical pictures(movies duh... with music). We got it all. Annie get your gun, Brigadoon(favorite of a ballet brother, and on and on.) Legacy of a musical mother. Now in my opinion this a great movie. Best I have seen in years. Period. Just bought it too. Can't wait to see it again. Those bum reviews in my opinion are just those poor souls that have no appreciation for a GREAT musical. Fantastic flow and story is magical. Great work to all involved. Nice cameo by the Abba boys on the cloud at the conclusion.
But this movie is so bad that I had to start.  Worst movie I've ever sat the entire way through.

This was the worst movie that I have ever seen. It was so bad, that it was painful to watch. I can't understand how you can gather some of the best actors on the planet, with some of the best music ever produced, and not be able to come up with even three minutes of watchable film. ?????
I could have picked random people off of the street, had them write their own tunes, and film it on a camcorder, and I swear that it would have been more interesting than this unbelievably horrifying excuse for a film. And this has to be said: Anybody who liked this movie must be so insanely starved for entertainment that they'd be amused by watching a plant grow.

I never got a chance to see Mama Mia at the movies, nor did I see the Broadway show. I really did not know about the story, except what I saw on TV promoting the movie.
I did purchase the Blue Ray disc, just knowing I would LOVE the movie, and I do (I Do, I Do, I Do...)... in fact, I have seen it twice in two days since it arrived at my house. I am enthralled with the story, the scenery, the actors, (Dominic Cooper is a REAL cutie!!) and the music was a real blast from my past. Who knew ABBA had so many fantastic songs??
So, sit down, turn on the tv, pop in the Blue Ray disc, crank up the surround sound and have a fantastic time... I did !!!!

For the sake of avoiding hyperbole I'll try not to say this is one of the most enjoyable musical romantic comedies I have ever seen. But I will say that it is an absolute joy to spend an hour forty minutes watching actors appearing as though they are enjoying themselves. And in Mamma Mia, every actor seems to be - well, to quote one of the songs - having the time of their lives. It's a sitcom storyline; the young bride played by Amanda Seyfried secretly invites her three possible biological fathers to her wedding and, as the saying goes, hilarity ensues. A superb cast is in attendance - though Seyfried's Sophie the central character, Meryl Streep gets top billing, and delivers a landmark performance befitting her status as one of the greatest contemporary actresses. So much for avoiding hyperbole, huh? She looks slim, happy, and beautiful. Also along for this fun ride are Pierce Brosnan, Colin Firth, Stellan Skarsgard, Christine Baranski, and one of my personal favorite actresses, Julie Walters, who is perhaps best known as Molly Weasley in the Harry Potter films, but I have also loved her in Billy Elliot and Educating Rita. The backdrop for all this fun is a seemingly timeless inn on a beautiful Greek island. All of the musical numbers are songs from the 70s Swedish vocal pop band ABBA. But wait. They are integrated beautifully into the story and Meryl Streep in particular shows a shocking capacity for acting through rages of emotion, in character while singing. And did I say it strongly enough? The absolute joy the actors seem to be having is infectious. You can't watch this movie while frowning. I don't care who you are, it will put a smile on your face. I watched the DVD from Netflix, and gave it 4 out of possible 5 stars in Netflix's rating system. Now I am going to buy it.  After I have watched it two or three more times I just might give it the full five stars that I usually reserve for Schindler's List league films. The DVD special features include an additional song that was deleted from the final edit, director comments, and a sing-along mode in which the lyrics are displayed during songs in karaoke fashion. The DVD was released December 16th in North America and November 27th in Europe. I recommend everyone give it a spin.

I just HAD to add my two cents worth to counter those one-star naysayers.  I never did enjoy a musical on the silver screen until I saw 'Mamma Mia'.  I actually went to see this movie for one thing and one thing only -- the MEN (well, two in particular: Brosnan and Firth).  I walked out of the movie theatre smiling, my 13-year-old daughter and I gushing about how awesome it was.  Yes, it's true, Brosnan can't sing but Firth has a decent enough voice (though he only did one number).  Streep, too, has a surprisingly good pair of lungs; her girl friends made for a strong supporting cast, both in the acting and the singing.  To those who don't think this movie is realistic, simple arithmatic will tell you that a 20-year-old girl in the 00s was NOT born of a relationship in the 70s!  So who cares?  It's just a fun movie -- watch it, enjoy it and stop mulling over every little detail!  I don't think the guys would enjoy this movie as much but, hey, we sit through enough shoot-'em-ups with them that they can watch this with us!  Ultimately, there will be two camps: the people (women) who loved the movie and those (men) who hated it.

About this Two-Disc Special Edition, I'm not sure what the other disc is since I bought the Full Screen edition.  The Full Screen edition was bare-bone basic consisting of only the disc itself and no inserts whatsoever so that was disappointing.  Maybe the Two-Disc edition will offer more (but it's good only if you have a WS telly).

I'm surprised at the negative reviews on this film; there must be a lot of curmudgeons out there.  First of all, most people who went to see Mamma Mia love ABBA and all their songs.  Obviously no one can sing these songs even half as well as ABBA did, but so what?  Bjorn and Benny's music is so wonderful it stands on its own no matter who sings it.  This film is fun, the gorgeous Greek setting makes it pure eye candy, the songs no matter how "imperfectly" they were sung are still infectious and make you want to jump out of your seat and dance, and you will sing along with most of them.  This movie does exceedingly well what it is supposed to do:  entertain.  As for the ABBA music, I probably wouldn't buy this soundtrack and rather, I would buy the original ABBA music if I wanted a CD of the songs on this film.

This was a great fun inspirational film.  Innocent and charming (well, with some small sexual innuendos).  But, here's how I see that some people will be divided on its overall appeal:

For people who've heard of ABBA and may know a couple of their songs, this film will definitely make you wanna run out and buy some ABBA CD's.  For those of us (like me) who already have all of ABBA's CD's and have cherished ABBA all their life, these actors singing ABBA songs is rather dull and much less energetically expressive than the ever-vivacious vocal outbursts of Annafrid and Agnetha (the original girls of ABBA).

The original songs from ABBA have incredibly talented harmonizing and enthusiasm.  None of these actors can hit the notes like Agnetha and Annafrid (also known as Frida) did in their day.  And especially Pierce Brosnan. This was an embarrassing transition from being a former James Bond.

However, I'm glad to see a movie made as a musical to many of ABBA's fabulous songs.  Pick up ABBA's greatest hits on CD, or just go ahead and get all eight of their original albums.  You will be in for a treat!

Let me give you one good example of the girls of ABBA belting their voices out so strong.  Go to YouTube and listen to ABBA's version of "Chiquitita", and concentrate of the voices and the fabulous background orchestration.  It is one of the greatest songs they've done which is a great example of their enormous talent.  ABBA will never be topped.

"Mamma Mia!" brings the wildly successful ABBA-inspired stage musical to the screen with a cast of actors who don't usually sing or dance. The film retains the behind-the-scenes talent from the stage show: director Phydilla Lloyd, producer Judy Craymer, writer Catherine Johnson, and score by former ABBA member Benny Andersson. It adds one song and leaves a few others out, but this is very much a transfer of the stage musical to the screen. A young woman named Sophie (Amanda Seyfried) plans to marry her beau Sky (Dominic Cooper) and dreams that her father will be at her wedding to give her away. But Sophie doesn't know who her father is. Twenty years ago, her mother Donna (Meryl Streep) had summer flings with three men. Sophie invites all three to her wedding in Greece in hopes that she will recognize her father. But when Donna sees the men from her past, she's sure that they will ruin the wedding.

There's hardly any point in mentioning that the set-up for this musical romp in the Greek Isles is silly beyond words. But the three candidates for Sophie's paternity are appealing guys, and the actors are game: American architect Sam Carmichael (Pierce Brosnan), British banker Harry Bright (Colin Firth), and Swedish adventurer and travel writer Bill Anderson (Stellan Skarsgard). The men are counterbalanced by a trio of sprightly middle-aged ladies: Donna and her friends Rosie the author (Julie Walters) and Tanya the serial divorcee (Christine Barnasky). These are fun characters, and I enjoyed them. I wish I could say the same for the younger set. Amanda Seyfried has a nice enough voice, but Sophie is annoying and seems more like a 13-year-old than a woman of 20.

The musical numbers are dull. I partly blame the lack of vigor on the locations. This is a jukebox musical, so the songs are not integrated into the plot as seamlessly as they would be if the music had been written for the stage. And since this is a movie, filmed on location in Greece, they don't have the benefit of an intimate venue. On stage in a small venue, energy would be flying off the stage. In these wide open locations, further muted by transfer to the screen, the musical numbers fall flat. I kept hoping that the next scene would not be musical, because the stuff in between was reasonably charming. The problem is exacerbated by the fact that most of the principle cast is over 50. Generally an appealing cast, even if they are not the best-suited talent for a musical, but unfortunately, the music that's supposed to be the selling point is the film's weakness.

The DVD (Universal 2008 single disc): The single disc edition has the option of viewing a Sing-a-Long version in which the lyrics to the songs are displayed across the screen during musical numbers. There is one deleted musical number called "The Name of the Game" (3 min). And there is a feature commentary by director Phyllida Lloyd. She talks about locations, some photographic techniques, characters, cast, filming, her approach to the musical numbers, and various technical details. Subtitles are available in English SDH, French, Spanish. Dubbing available in Spanish, French.

I rarely write reviews but I had to chime in on this one!  Before I knew it, I found myself dancing in my seat, tapping my feet, humming along, smiling, and sitting until the very ending of the credits and singing along once more to the songs.  I couldn't care less if Pierce Bronsen can carry a tune or not; this is simply a delightful, funny, and charismatic way to spend almost 2 hours.

Mamma Mia! The Movie (Two Disc Special Edition) is an uplifting celebration of life, love and friendship -- plus the complications of such. Meryl Streep is phenomenal in her role as the single mother who runs a hotel on a Greek island. This movie is worth seeing just for the beautiful scenes of the islands...But the performances of Streep, Amanda Seyfried, Julie Walters and Christine Baranski turns this into a fabulous song fest. Pierce Brosnan and Colin Firth are hilarious as contenders for "father", along with Stellan Skarsgard. While the story may seem trite -- love wins out, etc. -- the gorgeous ABBA tunes sweep across the beautiful settings, creating a crescendo of glory as the characters bask in the beauty of life and nature. What more could one want? Laurel-Rain Snow Author of: Web of Tyranny, etc.

Meryl Streep is pretty good.  Pierce Brosnan is awful - he can't sing and shouldn't try.  There is a kind of peculiar slant to this movie - all the strong roles go to women - the men are weak and have marginal roles.  Most of the emotional and physical intimacy is between women with men shut out.  If this is your cup of tea, you might like this movie.

Look, I'm here to help you. Hopefully, you'll read this review before the Holidays and you'll buy or rent something worthy of your friends and family to view, something like Sin City or Death Proof but please God, not Mamma Mia. This film is so bad that the people who didn't walk out after 15 minutes decided it was better to just make fun of it by making inappropriate and often times hilarious comments throughout. There's you're warning. Now if you're still intent on seeing this film because Meryl Streep is in it, I want you to remember one thing. This is the same woman who made She-Devil with Roseanne Bar in 1989. Save yourselves.
Your welcome.

I have seen the play on Broadway 5 times and fell in love.  Yes, I agree that the movie does not compare despite the scenery, wonderful actors and fantastic story line, but I have watched the dvd 3 times in the 2 days since it arrived.  That says something. You can't help but love the music and sing along, with or without the available subtitles. The songs did not flow as easily as they did in the play because I did not feel like the actors were in sync with the music in spots but they did a great job at something quite foreign to most of them and it was wonderful none the less.  I highly recommend this to Abba lovers and musical lovers of all ages.  I bought the 2 dvd set and the extras I have seen so far were well worth the extra few dollars.  Can't wait to go watch it again.  I was hoping for so long that they would turn the play into a movie and I am so glad they did and picked a perfect cast to do it!!  Thank you for giving me something I can enjoy over and over without having to leave the house.

Meryl Streep plays a single mom whose daughter Sophie is about to be married.  Sophie has never known who her father is and in an attempt to find out she does a bit of detective work via her mom's diary.  She discovers that there are three men who potentially could be her dad, and she invites them all to the wedding unbeknowst to her mother.

Watching Meryl Streep and her two buddies recreate their old singing group or Meryl Streep singing to her daughter who is about to be wed will take you from cheers to tears.  Streep's acting abilities translate beautifully to her singing, whether it's a teary-eyed mother reminiscing about her daughter's childhood or a feisty middle-aged woman leading the other local women in a rousing Abba song.  This movie is just plain fun, so watch it and enjoy!

Sophie has been raised on a remote Greek island by her mother Donna (Meryl Streep).  Donna has never told Sophie who her father is, and that has left a hole in Sophie's heart.

But as her wedding to Sky (Dominic Cooper) nears, Sophie finds a journal her mother kept 21 years ago.  In it, she finds three potential candidate for her father, Sam (Pierce Brosnan), Harry (Colin Firth), and Bill (Stellan Skarsgard).  Convinced that she will know her father on sight, she invites all three men without telling her mother.  But when all three men arrive, Sophie finds herself just as confused as she was before.  And their presence just complicates the wedding plans even further.  Will Donna recover from the surprise?  Will Sophie figure out who her father is?  Will the men discover why they are there?  And just how many great songs can be used to capture the feelings of the characters?

I was not familiar with ABBA before I saw the movie, so pretty much had no clue what to expect.  And I loved these songs.  Honestly, if I didn't know where the music originated, I would have told you all the songs were written for the musical.  Not bad for a concept I dismissed as silly a few years back.  But these pop/rock sounds fit the story perfectly.

And this cast can sing!  Meryl Streep is especially impressive as Donna, and gets the most songs.  The emotion she gets into so many of the songs is outstanding but hardly surprising considering how great an actress she is.  The only weak link in the singing department was Pierce Brosnan.  He is adequate while the others are outstanding.  But that's a minor point.

With the number of songs in the movie, there is no way that they can develop all the characters well, especially since the film is under two hours.  Donna and her two friends are the best developed, followed by Sophie.  Honestly, I was disappointed with how little development Sky got.  I thought he'd play a bigger role.  And I had a hard time keeping the back story on the three potential dads straight.

But I was certainly pulled into the story, wanting to know how things would end.  I felt the climax was rushed to make way for one more song, the only time I felt that way about the story.

This movie will leave you humming a tune with a smile on your face.  That's all I ask from a musical.

Mamma Mia! is a stage musical with a book by British playwright Catherine Johnson, based on the songs of ABBA, composed by Benny Andersson and Bjrn Ulvaeus. It is an example of a jukebox musical, and is notable for popularizing the genre. A common misconception is that the plot is adapted from the 1968 film Buona Sera, Mrs. Campbell starring Gina Lollobrigida. (In that film the mother is a former prostitute who told all three men that they were the father to secure payment for her child's upkeep. This differs vastly from the Mamma Mia story. Donna is not based on a prostitute and the writers deny any knowledge of the 1968 film, any similarity is coincidental.)

Although the title of the musical is taken from the group's 1975 chart-topper Mamma Mia, the plot is fictional, not biographical.

Bjrn Ulvaeus and Benny Andersson, who composed the original music for ABBA, were involved in the development of the show from the beginning. Anni-Frid Lyngstad has been involved financially in the production, while Agnetha Fltskog has not, though she was present at the Swedish premiere and final show.

The musical includes such hits as "Super Trouper", "Dancing Queen", "Knowing Me, Knowing You", "Thank You for the Music", "Money, Money, Money", "The Winner Takes It All", "Voulez Vous", "I Have a Dream" and "SOS". It had been seen by over ten million people worldwide as of July 2003.[1] Estimates of 2007, is that 30 million have now seen Mamma Mia!. Since its opening in 1999, the production has grossed US$2.0 billion in earnings. [2]

A stage-to-film adaptation, Mamma Mia! The Movie, starring Meryl Streep, Colin Firth, Pierce Brosnan, Amanda Seyfried, Christine Baranski and Julie Walters, premiered in July 2008Mamma Mia! The Movie is a 2008 Golden Globe-nominated stage-to-film adaptation of the 1999 West End musical of the same name, based on the songs of successful pop group ABBA, with additional music also composed by ABBA member Benny Andersson. The film did very well at the box office becoming the most successful Hollywood film musical of all time and the highest grossing film of all time in the United Kingdom.[2] Like the stage musical, the film's title originates from the group's 1975 chart-topper Mamma Mia. It was produced by Universal Pictures in partnership with Playtone and Littlestar.[3]

Meryl Streep heads the cast of the film, playing the role of single mother Donna Sheridan. Pierce Brosnan, Colin Firth, and Stellan Skarsgrd play the three possible fathers to Donna's daughter Sophie (Amanda Seyfried).

On August 29, 2008, Mamma Mia!: The Sing-Along Edition, with lyrics to the songs highlighted on the screen, was released in select theaters.[4]

On December 15, 2008, it was announced that Mamma Mia! had become the highest grossing film in Britain of all time. The previous record was held by Titanic in 1998. The film takes place on the enchanting Greek island of Skopelos (Kalokairi). The story begins at the remote Aegean island hotel, Villa Donna, run by Donna Sheridan (Meryl Streep), her daughter Sophie (Amanda Seyfried), and Sophie's fiance Sky (Dominic Cooper).

Prior to her forthcoming marriage, Sophie nervously posts three wedding invitations ("I Have a Dream") to three different men, one of whom she believes may be her father. From three cities across the globe, three men set off to return to the island, and the woman that had enchanted each of them 20 years earlier.

Back on that island, Donna is rousing her staff for the frenetic day ahead as Sophie's bridesmaids and best friends Ali and Lisa (Ashley Lilley and Rachel McDowall) arrive and she shares with her best mates a scandalous secret: Sophie has found her mother's diary and learned she has three possible dads; American businessman Sam Carmichael (Pierce Brosnan), Swedish adventurer Bill Austin (Stellan Skarsgard), and British banker Harry Bright (Colin Firth). Without telling her mother, she has invited all three to her wedding ("Honey, Honey"), believing that after she spends time with them, she will at last know who her real father is.

Meanwhile, back on the Greek mainland, Sam, Bill, and Harry; strangers until today have met at the harbor. Fortuitously, Sam and Harry have missed the ferry to Skopelos (Kalokairi), and Bill offers them a lift on his yacht to reconnect with the woman who broke all their hearts 20 years ago.

Back on Skopelos, Donna is ecstatic to reunite with old friends and former "Donna and The Dynamos" bandmates, wisecracking author Rosie (Julie Walters) and wealthy multiple divorcee Tanya (Christine Baranski), and reveals her mystification at her daughter's desire for a traditional wedding or any wedding at all. At the Villa, Sophie introduces Tanya and Rosie to true love Sky, and tells them about their idea of designing a website to attract tourists to the island. Donna explains her precarious finances ("Money, Money, Money") to her girlfriends as she takes them on a tour of the Villa. Hounded by her creditors, Donna dreams of a "rich man's world," sunbathing on a yacht and being deliciously pampered. She is brought back to reality as an ominous crack appears in the courtyard.

The three men arrive, and Sophie smuggles them to their quarters and sheepishly explains that she, not her mother, sent the invitations. She begs the men to hide so Donna will have a fantastic surprise at the wedding; seeing the old friends of whom she "so often" favorably speaks. They overhear Donna working (humming "Fernando" to herself) in the storeroom below preparing to fix the crack and the men swear to Sophie they will not reveal her secret. Sophie leaves by the window just in the nick of time, as Donna peeps through the trapdoor.

She is dumbfounded to find herself face to face with the three former lovers she could never forget ("Mamma Mia!"), while the men clumsily make up excuses for their presence. Donna is adamant; they simply cannot stay. Visibly shaken, she confides in Tanya and Rosie ("Chiquitita") a secret she has kept from everyone - she is uncertain which of the three men is actually Sophie's father. No matter, as Tanya and Rosie rally her spirits by getting Donna to join in with the female staff and islanders accompanying a musical number intended to make her forget her woes. Donna and The Dynamos reclaim their glory days and champion the women of the island in a call to liberation ("Dancing Queen").

Sophie finds the men aboard Bill's yacht, and they take a trip around the gorgeous island of Skopelos ("Our Last Summer") and tell her stories of Donna as a carefree girl. Upon their return, Sophie musters up the courage to speak with Sky about her ploy, but loses her nerve. Sky and Sophie sing passionately to each other ("Lay All Your Love on Me"), but are interrupted by the bachelor party that has descended upon Sky to kidnap him for his last night of freedom.

At Sophie's bachelorette party, Donna, Tanya, and Rosie perform in a surprise one-night-only event as Donna and The Dynamos ("Super Trouper"). Sophie is delighted to see her mother rock out, but becomes nervous when the festivities are interrupted by the arrival of Sam, Bill and Harry. She decides to get each of her three prospective dads alone to talk.

The young bride uses the confusion of her amorous girlfriends' dancing with the men ("Gimme! Gimme! Gimme! (A Man After Midnight)") to speak with Sam about his love for Donna. Next, she's on to Harry about his desire, if any, for children.
